scenes.location: COLETTE FAMILY HOME BEDROOM EARLY MORNING 2
characters: MUSIC COMES UP AND CONTINUES THROUGH THE FOLLOWING MONTAG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first light is breaking over the fields and hedges of this timeless rural landscape. With the clanking of bells a herd of cows makes its way to the first milking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is simple with a few sticks of worn wooden furniture. A young woman is asleep under the covers, with cat curled up on the bottom of the bed. This is GABRIELLE SIDONIE COLETTE, or as she will later be known, simply COLETTE. A voice calls from down the corridor - her mother SIDO.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gabrielle! The girl stirs but her eyes remain stubbornly closed.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gabrielle!! Wake up.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Let me sleep!

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Come on, Gabrielle!! Sido is now at the door frame. A handsome country woman, forthright and practical - nobody’s fool.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: It’s 8 o’clock. Willy is coming today. Colette just murmurs. SIDO (cont’d) (CONT'D) Good. Then you won’t want your hair doing. She disappears. After a moment, a head emerges from under the pillow and looks to the empty doorway. We get our fir look at the milky skinned, precocious, whip-smart, Colett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train belches steam as it slowly moves toward the stati A MAN IN A TOP HAT leans out of the window.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismounting, Willy sees a waiting carriage across the pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing her best frock, Colette carries a large TEA SERVI down a corridor and into the main room. Willy is seated, conversation with Sido and JULES, the patriarch, an affab old soldier, with one leg, who is smoking a pipe.

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: And how is Paris these days, Willy?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s a hot bed! It’s “Electric!” Heaving with artists, writers, poets, all seeking to say something profound... most of them are too young or crazed but still, they do generate a certain... life force! Colette, her hair neatly plaited, puts the cups out for everyone then takes over the teapot and pours.

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: We were going to see a play in Paris - weren’t we?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: La Tosca.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I was at the opening. I wouldn’t bother, quite frankly. Sarah Bernhardt did her best, she always does, but the piece is too overwrought in a particularly feminine way... melodramatic in extremis! Tears on the stage but all dry eyes in the house.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Maybe I'11 go and make up my own mind.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well, just remember... if a book bores you, you can throw it away. If a painting is garish, you close your eyes. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whereas bad theatre is like dentistry; you are compelled to stay in the chair, having your skull drilled, until the entire grizzly procedure is over.

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: Good point, Willy. Painful business!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Though I imagine it must hold a secret source of enjoyment - for the dentist. Willy raises an appreciative eyebrow and chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Indeed... Oh - I almost forgot. A small gift. He reaches in his pocket and pulls out a small package. S unwraps it to find a SNOW GLOBE OF PARIS.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’ve read about these.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Shake it. She does and looks, fascinated, at the twirling flakes.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Look, Sido. A snow globe. She holds it up for her mother. EXT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE — LATE AFTERNOON 7 M. Willy bids good-bye to Jules, Sido and Colette, before the carriage moves off. Colette is holding her comfortabl old cat which she hands off to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Sido, I’m going for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Change your dress first.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’1l stay on the path.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Change it!  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in a different dress, Colette starts to come down sta Hearing her parents talking in the kitchen, she slows up, listening carefully.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s something about him I find suspect... something disingenuous.

dialogues.speaker: JULES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, not in my reckoning... He’s a good man. He has a reputation, yes, but there comes a time ina man’s life to settle down...and she’s the right age for it. She’ll be twenty next time around.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I just worry that he won’t understand her. That girl said her first word at nine months. She was always reading, way ahead of her class, she was the lead in the school play - every year.

dialogues.speaker: JULES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My dear, would anyone be good enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Hmmph. Now on the ground floor Colette waits outside the door as her parents talk. Sido moves into view by the kitchen sin

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you finished the letter to his father?

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: I keep starting but I can’t seem to finish it. A girl without a dowry, -that just doesn’t happen in their circles. They may cut him off if he marries her.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: So they call it off. The world won't end. As her father talks, Colette sneaks back up the last five stairs...  10 11 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 5.

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: Sido, he clearly adores her - he’s visited four times. He’ll give her status, not to mention a tremendous cultural life - the theater, the opera. He’1ll give her Paris for heaven's sakes! Colette comes clumping down the stairs, slightly too loud and into the room.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Can I go now?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Yes. Take this - for blackberries. (hands her a pot) I’m making a tart tomorrow. And don’t be late back.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (eye roll) I won't... Sido watches her daughter, not without suspicion, as she takes off across the garden. EXT. SAINT-SAUVEUR — COUNTRYSIDE - LATE AFTERNOON 9 Colette runs down a path, then backs up, picks a few prim blackberries, and continues on. She moves through the woods, with the stealth of an anima then breaks out across a broad green meadow towards a bar EXT. OLD BARN — LATE AFTERNOON 10 She approaches the gaping black door of a dilapidated bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering the darkness, Colette blinks to re-adjust her eyes. A flutter of wings attracts her attention. She turn to see an ascending pigeon. Then, below, a tired old hors

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Over here. Enjoying the simple pleasures of country life! Behind a partition, she sees Willy, reclining on a pile o straw.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 6.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You look at home in the hay.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I think I might be! And you look like a beautiful young country girl. Right there. With the light...What’s that? Colette shows him, putting the bowl between them as she nestles beside him. Her hands are blue with the juice. She looks WILLY (CONT’D) Your fingers are stained. (he takes her hand) Mm... Maybe I could just leave Paris behind. (he takes a blackberry) You could feed me berries. I’d catch a fish with my teeth. Then come back here to my cave. Like a bear. Bliss.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (he caresses her braids) Your hair is a phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: In the village, they call me “the girl with the hair.”

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I can see why. I’m sure you’re famous here in your village.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: A little. down. COLETTE (cont'd) (CONT'D) How long until your train goes?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: In about 40 minutes. But I have to walk to the station.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Normally takes me about 15 minutes. Will probably take you 20.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 7.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Right. So if my calculations are correct...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: We have time - if we’re quick.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, we do. He smiles, moved by her beauty, kisses her, then breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I just can’t say how unimaginably happy I am, Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: So am I. He holds her by her shoulders firmly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I adore you. He kisses her shoulder. Feeling his beard brush against h skin, Colette smiles as they move into a passionate embra nearby horse chews hay as they proceed to take their clot off. 11A INT. COLETTE’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 11A Colette sprawls out on the bed, her hair in plaits. She i writing a letter in a school exercise book in pencil, res on an encyclopaedia.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Dear Willy, As I walked home by the river, the light shining through the trees, my heart filled with a kind of delicious pride. After all, you know all those fine women of Paris...so I must have something. (smiles to herself) ) I want to wake up next to you. Trace your profile with my finger while you sleep. Know that the day is ours. That life is ours for the taking. We will be so entire and so happy, my love.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Wedding Party, Jules is making a toast Colette and Willy in front of a MIXED CROWD of WEDDING GUESTS.

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: It’s the proudest time in a father’s life, but also - I now find - one of the saddest. I have to hand over my beloved daughter, who has lit up our lives for so long, with her wit, her brilliance, her beauty. I will miss you, Gabrielle. Almost as much as your mother will... A murmur of acknowledgement from the assembled. Colette smiles at her father, and catches her mother’s eye, holdi back emotion.

dialogues.speaker: JULES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it is no small compensation that I give her to a man of such inestimable standing. There are many celebrities in Paris but few are famous enough to be known by -- by a single name. WILLY - Welcome to the Colette family. Everyone cheers. Colette turns to her new husband, glowing.

dialogues.speaker: SOME TIME LATER
dialogues.text: A COUNTRY BAND strikes up. COUPLES polka around the garden. A COUPLE OF PEASANTS carry trays of drinks from a kitchen tent to the GUESTS. Some CHILDREN chase a chicken through dancers. WILLY (cont'd) This is definitely a country wedding.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’ll make a good story -- in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You'll be the story in Paris, Gabrielle. Just wait ‘til they get a look at you. Willy twirls Colette round and round and round...  13 14 15 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the river Seine - the center of the demi-monde; th Left Bank. This is not postcard Paris - the buildings are sooty and chimneys are filling the sky with smoke. On the quay, PEOPLE go about their business as a YOUNG ATTENDANT lights the gas lamp. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - BOUDOIR - EVENING 14 MATILDE, the maid, is winching Colette into a very tight red froufrou dress. A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (0.8)
dialogues.text: Are you ready yet?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No - not yet. (to the maid) What do you think, Matilde?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDE
dialogues.text: It’s pretty, Madame. Colette looks at herself critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy returns and prepares to knock again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (0.8)
dialogues.text: We should try to get there before it ends.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m coming... The door opens. Colette is in another dress - the one fro their meeting in Saint-Sauveur. Matilde hovers nervously. COLETTE (CONT’D) Is the carriage waiting? Willy looks disappointed but together they proceed throug SEVERAL ROOMS to the front door. We get a feeling for Wil apartment - a warren of dark rooms overcrowded by boxes, and Wagnerian bric-a-brac. Willy, it seems, is a hoarder.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Where’s your new dress?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It looks ridiculous. I couldn't breathe in it.  16 17 18 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 10.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: That thing cost me two hundred and thirty-seven francs.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I know. We'll get it adjusted.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (half joking) More money! They exit. EXT. ELEGANT PARISIAN STREET — EARLY EVENING 16 The carriage pulls up. Colette is fiddling with a spot of tooth powder on her dress.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ...It’s tooth paste.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (amused) My God! Here... He rubs a little spit on it. WILLY (CONT’D) That’1ll do. Let’s go in... INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — HALLWAY 17 They approach the giant door.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ready for the lions...? She lets out a nervous exhale. The double doors glide ope INT. MADAME DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - MAIN ROOM 18 Willy and Colette proceed into a reception room filled wi the beautiful, the sparkling, and the eccentric of Paris’ Golden Age. The mirrors have been polished; so have the epigrams. Amidst the gas lamps, the India rubber plants, and the zebra skin rugs, the energy is bouncing off the walls. Willy acknowledges hellos and nods to people along the wa With her tight braids and country dress, Colette looks dr in this sea of peacocks.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 11. They arrive at a circle of conversation -- that of MME. D CAILLAVET, the hostess, the debonair COUNT MUFFAT, and a few SALONITES and FRIENDS.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: It’s monstrous. I can’t look at it.

dialogues.speaker: COUNT MUFFAT
dialogues.text: At least it’s temporary.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: Oh here’s Willy -- Willy! Eiffel’s Tower, are you for or against?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’m for it, if a little jealous of this giant erection in the heart of our capital... belonging to someone else. Laughter from the circle.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: You rogue, Willy. And you’ve brought a... an orphaned relative?

dialogues.speaker: COUNT MUFFAT
dialogues.text: A secret love child?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (acknowledging their mockery) Very good... May I present to you my wife, Gabrielle-Sidonie Colette. Colette curtsies politely, her cheeks flushing.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: Delighted. Well, astonished actually. You have caught the slipperiest eel... How does one do that?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure... Colette smiles, a little nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: Where are you from, you sweet thing?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 12.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m from Saint-Sauveur-en-Puisaye... (no reaction) ...it’s in Burgundy.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: Hence the dress!

dialogues.speaker: COUNT MUFFAT
dialogues.text: Have you “relocated,” Willy? This is apparently hilarious and there is laughter.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: Tst...ignore him... But how on earth did you two meet?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Our fathers served together in the army...

dialogues.speaker: COUNT MUFFAT
dialogues.text: (riding over her) Willy married! The wild days are done, eh?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You’re quite mistaken, sir. The wild days have just begun. Willy smiles at his new bride’s moxie. A business-like young man rushes up to Willy. This is PIERRE VEBER.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: Willy, thank God you're back. That short story for La Forgue —

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Pierre. Let me introduce you to my wife, Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: What..? Very pleased to meet you. Before she can speak, he turns to Willy with a more urgen VEBER (CONT’D) It’s due on Tuesday and you haven’t given me the slightest clue.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Amuse yourself for a moment, Gabrielle.  19 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 13.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I will. Willy draws Veber aside to continue the shop talk.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s simple - an eight hundred word sketch. Small coastal resort, damp bathing-costumes. The perfect place to rejuvenate a de-iodized constitution. A buxom girl approaches, long legs... Colette is left standing by herself. Nearby, a silver tra displays a living turtle with an exquisitely jeweled shel She takes a lettuce leaf from a salad dish and feeds it.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Poor thing. You want the earth and the grass don’t you? Across the room she sees Willy, with Veber, lifting the g on a wall candle and lighting a cigar. Feeling out of sorts, she moves through to an adjacent ro where... INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — MUSIC ROOM 19 A STRING QUARTET is giving a recital to the assembled. Across the room a group of SALONITES are clearly discussi her. Embarrassed, Colette finds an empty seat. She looks across the room - the salonites are still whispering.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Are your ears burning? Colette looks up and sees - Marcel SCHWOB, an intellectua with a humane gleam in his eye. He sits next to her. SCHWOB (CONT’D) I’m Schwob, a friend of Willy's.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Hello. I’m Gabrielle. Willy described you to me.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: I hope he was kind.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (wryly) Hope costs nothing.  20 21 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 14. Schwob raises an amused eyebrow, then looks out into the room where people are stealing glances at them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: The modern day mob, aren’t they? (Colette nods) But their goddess is gossip instead of the guillotine. Are you feeling overwhelmed?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: They may look grand and intimidating. But just imagine them shitting. Each and every one of them. Colette looks at him, incredulous. SCHWOB (CONT’D) Well they all do, don’t they? Across the room, AN IMPORTANT-LOOKING GENTLEMAN, waves to Schwob. SCHWOB (CONT’D) (to the Gentleman) Good evening, Sir! (to Colette) Try it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They may look grand and intimidating. But just imagine them perched over a chamber pot. Each and every one of them. INT. MADAME DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - VARIOUS ROOMS 20 We follow Colette as she searches for Willy in the sea of SOCIALITES. She walks through rooms where PEOPLE are now dancing in an avant garde fashion then through a series o SMALLER COMPARTMENTS, where SERVANTS are polishing glasse and CHEFS are preparing hors d’oeuvres, past palms and oi lamps, to a distant room at the far end of the salon. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — SMOKING ROOM 21 From the doorway, Colette spies Willy leaning on the mantelpiece talking to a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN in a red dress. The woman leans in close to him, laughing. He whispers something and she laughs even harder.  22 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 15. There's a shrieking coming from the corner of the main ro Colette turns to sees the crowd laughing as a BOHEMIAN po milk into an upright piano. INT. HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE — MOVING — NIGHT 22 Colette looks out the window into the night-time streets. After a moment, Willy ventures a question.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: So what did you think of the salon? WILLY (CONT’D) That was essentially - what you witnessed tonight - everyone who’s anyone in Paris...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Was it..?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Who did you like? Who did you talk to?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I liked the tortoise. I think he was as bored as I was.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I suspect you were more intimidated than bored?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. I found them...shallow. Pretentious.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ah, you're reading them wrongly. It’s not pretension so much as exaggeration. The ideal is to be authentic yet larger than life. To present a personality with a capital P. You could do it too with your country girl charm ... She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Did that woman have a capital P?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Which one?  23 24 25 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 16.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: The one you were talking to? In the red dress. With the breasts?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Nicole D’Allier? That was just... flirtation. It means absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Then why do it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s what one does... to pass the time. It staves off boredom. You’re reading it all completely wrong. Colette sighs, frustrated. Willy changes tack.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Forget about all of them now. Any way - haven’t you heard the news? Willy is married. Happily married. And he’s going home with his bride, who he loves very much. Colette nods, looks at him with a half-smile. He is forgi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage rides off into the distance. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - MORNING 2 From directly above, we see Pierre Veber dash up the stairs. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - ENTRANCE ROOM 25 Colette is seated at a desk, carefully roughing out a letter. She writes a line then crosses it out, rephrases it. There’s a knock at the door. Veber enters in the hallway and looks through to Colette’s small room where she sits with a large pile of correspondence.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Hello, Veber.  26 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 17.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: Gabrielle. It’s cold out there today.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m under house arrest so it doesn’t affect me. (gestures to the other room) Schwob’s already in there. We follow Veber through the maze-like apartment to Willy' office. He passes through the front room which is semi-da its furniture covered by dust sheets. INT. WILLY’S STUDY 26 Willy, mid-flow, barely notices Veber enter. Schwob sits an oil lamp, taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: So something like...”all the humor and vivacity descends into...a dreadful melodramatic swamp! Or... it released the toxins of man’s very soul, leaving the audience pale, and nauseous as though having eaten a bad oyster.”

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: It’s a bit extreme. The ending was actually quite touching. Willy thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Hmmph - I prefer my version. He finally acknowledges the new arrival. WILLY (CONT’D) Veber!

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: Willy. Schwob.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (to Schwob) So drop in those embellishments and file it at The Echo before six.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Will do. (he leaves.)  27 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 18.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: The factory’s on fire... We’re on fire...! Sit. I’ve hada remarkable idea - it could be, anyway...

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’m going to launch a novel.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We've had stories by Willy, music reviews by Willy. Now Willy’s first novel. There’1l be enough literature in it to appeal to the high-brows and enough filth for the great unwashed.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: And who's going to write it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: -.-You are! Veber shakes his head, absorbing this. WILLY (CONT’D) Brandy? Cigar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schwob stops to chat to Colette by the desk. Matilde is stoking the fire.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Are you writing for him too? He’s made you one of his ghosts already?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Just letters...

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: You're fastidious... exacting.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: A lot of crossing out, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: ...well, yes.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 19.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy copies them out afterwards - so they are in his handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: MATILDE
dialogues.text: No one has handwriting like M. Willy. 28 INT. WILLY’S STUDY 28 Willy is completely absorbed in his pitch, sweat beading from his forehead as he paces.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: He first sees her, Monna, held aloft on the shoulders of her admirers.. She’s eighteen, beautiful, wild and she’s from the streets, eats men up, never wears a corset. And our hero, Renaud - a writer, a genius - he’s captivated by her. She seduces him in her shabby rooms - five entire days of carnal bliss - but she has a powerful hold over him. She instinctively understands his base desires. We wonder - will Renaud escape - go back to his wholesome friends and his burgeoning career - or will he be dragged down by her toxic embrace, forgetting all about writing to live forever in a sexual quagmire. .? Willy ends with a flourish, eyes slightly damp. 29 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT 29 Colette gets up from her desk, as Willy escorts Veber through the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: How long do you think it will take?

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: Two or three months?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No no...weeks, Veber! It has to be weeks! Write for four hours at a time...

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: All right... I’1l1 come back to you if I get stuck.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 20.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes...Just write it...and fast! Let’s get some money coming in.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Gabrielle. She waves. The door closes on Veber. A piece of wallpaper has pulled free of the wall. Willy rubs it back in place.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Chaos. Working in these conditions. Absolute...chaos. Willy comes over to his wife and kisses her as they walk back into the front room. WILLY (CONT’D) You’ve married a literary entrepreneur. What a phenomenal disaster.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You’ve married a country girl. Not a penny to her name.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We're utterly doomed aren’t we? They both laugh. She hands him the rough draft of the letter. He peruses it quickly. WILLY (CONT’D) Perfect... but how about; “The contract you have sent me seems eminently fair, with only one shortcoming - the money.” Always pump something up before you prick it. You get more of a “POP” that way. Unexpectedly, Willy farts.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Intimacy in all its savage abandon, my love! I’ve a few meetings today. Let’s meet at La Mascotte at nine. No make it ten.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ..-Goodbye Willy.  30 31 32 33 34 35 36 37 38 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21. Colette watches him go. MUSIC COMES UP FOR THE NEXT

dialogues.speaker: A PANE OF GLASS 30
dialogues.text: It is greenish, uneven, and mottled. Using a tiny pair of scissors, a hand is etching the letter "W.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, Colette, Schwob, Veber and a COQUETTE, are finishi up a meal, drinking champagne. Willy is regaling them wit an anecdote as he pays the bill with a roll of notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willy walks down the aisle toward his seat, he is in h element. He nods acknowledgements and greetings to everybody who is anybody. Colette follows a couple of ste behind. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - ENTRANCE ROOM - DAY We see the etching progress - WIL. The creator is none other than Colette, alone, absorbed in this labor of love

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette starts pulling sheets off old furniture in the living room and opening up the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In bed together, Willy is reading the evening paper as Co nuzzles into his chest. He indicates a cartoon drawing - himself with his trademark top hat - that Colette finds amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette completes the etching of W I LL Y on the kitchen window, taking a moment to admire her handiwork. MUSIC ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette walks towards home, turns into the courtyard and collects the mail. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - HALLWAY/LIVING ROOM She enters, already opening the envelope and walks throug the house perusing the letter - that is written in green ink.  39 40 4l 42 43 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 22.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (murmuring) No...you’re a liar. Disgusted, she crumples it and throws it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow close on Colette as she walks determinedly. The streets seem abrasive, dirty, polluted. Several STREET WALKERS ignore her as she walks by. She checks the addres on the crumpled letter, looks up at the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette walks across the courtyard, up the stairs, across balcony and tries the door to a small apartment. It’s locked. Then she hears a familiar voice and moves over to look through a small window. INT. LOTTE KINCELER’S APARTMENT - LATE AFTERNOON 4l

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s 153 plus 278 plus 34 plus 106 for your hats... That makes it 571. For one month, Lotte...

dialogues.speaker: LOTTE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to look cheap? Willy is with the voluptuous LOTTE KINCELER. Between them the damning evidence: an accounting ledger.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: But for that money I could be laid five times as often by a prostitute. EXT. LOTTE’S KINCELER’S APARTMENT - LATE AFTERNOON 42 There’s the sound of a woman’s raucous laughter. Colette turns to see TWO SEX-WORKERS across the courtyard. As she turns back, Willy sees her at the window. Lotte instinctively grabs a pair of dressmakers scissors.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear. You’ve come to fetch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now walking back down the stairs, Colette is struggling mightily to keep her emotions in check as Willy blusters.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 23.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: She’s not a disreputable woman. There’s even a play about her - it’s a shit play but nevertheless... I wonder who the hell wrote that letter?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t care who wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: She’s no rival to you, Gabrielle. I promise, I’1l never sleep with her again. But - you have to understand - this is what men do. We are the weaker sex. We don’t have your strength. We are simply slaves to our urges. And here in the city - it’s perfectly acceptable to... Colette flies at him with inarticulate rage.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t accept it! You’ve been lying to me. All this time! I wait for you all day long! And I never ask you for anything because you say we have no money.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s true - we have no money.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Because you spend it all on her!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I really don’t!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Then when you get into our bed...and I touch you...and I kiss you...and you say you’re too tired...every night...no! No!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’ve been inattentive. I’1l make amends. He reaches out to her.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare touch me! She spits out the words with such venom that they bring h to a halt as she walks on.  44 45 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 24.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Gabrielle! I gave up my inheritance for you! My bloody freedom!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Go to hell! She exits through the large beaten-up gateway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train pulls into the station. A solitary figure waits the platform - Sido. EXT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE — BACKYARD - DAY 45 Sido and Colette are hanging out laundry. Colette seems t be only half-listening - her mind is elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: ...the Laurent girl had her baby last week. It was over nine pounds, but she managed well enough. She called her “Monique Frangoise.” The christening is next month. Oh, and the Durands moved away.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: He inherited a house. In Lorraine. I‘1l miss them. Colette manages a half smile.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m glad that you’re home. How long do you think you'll stay?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Sido.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: It must seem boring to you. Compared to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. Not at all.  46 47 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 25. INT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE - PARLOR — DAY 46 Colette is stretched out on a sofa, reading a book, absently stroking a cat in her lap. A loud clock is ticking. Sido appears at the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: You must eat something.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: You’re always hungry. Gabrielle... you’re not..? {pregnant}

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. I’1l eat later. Sido turns to leave but looks back at Colette.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Come outside. Help me with the tomatoes. EXT. SIDO’S KITCHEN GARDEN - DAY 47 Colette and Sido are kneeling together in the soil. They tie some young tomato plants. An ANT crawls up one of the stems.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Agh - ants. There must be honeydew...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (feels the leaf) Yes.. it’s sticky.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: The white flies have probably got to it. They'll have sucked all the juice.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: We need some ladybirds?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Or a spider. There’s a big one that’s dangling in my room. I'1l catch her and put her to work out here. Colette stops, looks at Sido.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 26.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Did you ever feel like you were playing a part, Sido?

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: As a wife... or a mother... That you were just going through the motions? Sido thinks. Inspects the other leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Sometimes as a wife.. Never as a mother. Why? Colette shakes her head, perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is he good to you Gabri..? (Colette’s eyes tear up) What is it, my love? Colette finally opens up...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Nothing’s how I imagined it.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Come here... Colette falls into her mother.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My darling kitten. No one can take away what you are - no one. You’re too strong for that. Always have been. Trust no one but yourself.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: What’s he done to upset you?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Nothing... Nothing. (she pulls away) It’s all - just - new... That’s all. I must get used to marriage. Sido nods, looks at her daughter who looks away.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Better to make marriage get used to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Colette walk along the dappled banks of the gre slow river. She is distant. He is persistent.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Are you happy to be here?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. It makes the city seem even more foul...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well, you are a country girl... She rolls her eyes. WILLY (CONT’D) Did you miss me?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (lies) No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Life has been...awful without you. Just dead. His tone grows more emotional. She holds firm. WILLY (CONT’D) I don’t feel like myself at all. Everything seems...utterly pointless. I can’t even write anymore... You mean more to me than all the women of Paris put together.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Have you sampled them all?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Please don’t mock me.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You’re happy to mock everybody else...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s true. It’s all horseshit... Words are deceptive little bastards... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: but if you trace mine to their source - to my bruised, aching heart...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t credit that as the organ of origin. He snorts.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You know me too well.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I can read you like the top line of an optician's chart.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful. Did you make it up? (she shakes her head exasperated) Just...tell me what you want, Gabrielle. And I’11l do it. She turns faces him.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Willy... And maybe I knew all along. But I want you not to lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I won't. Never again! I promise.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be treated like a little wife at home. I want to know what’s going on. Whatever it May be. I want to be... part of things.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You will be. You will be part of everything. He gives her his most sincere eyes. He puts his arms roun her and their voices get quieter as they walk further awa WILLY (CONT’D) ...and I’1ll even buy you a dog.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m being serious.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 29.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: So am I. (he looks around) This river is so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, me and Luce used to come swimming here after school.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You did? She was your best friend, wasn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No - but she was always with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy is now in bed, Colette is undressing. They talk quietly so as not to wake Sido.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Sometimes she could be sweet.. but she could also be very annoying.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Well, she was clumsy, more than anything. One day in winter, when the first snows started, I made a compact little snowball and smuggled it into the classroom. As Miss Terrain was writing I passed it along to the next person.. She strips down to her underclothes, shivers slightly.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brrrrrr.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Get in. I’m like a pot-bellied stove. Colette gets in and clings to him. Willy warms her hands.  50 51 52 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 30.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It finally got to Luce.. who “dropped” it..We both got detention. ..she’d do anything to be close to me. Willy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I bet she did. He kisses her. They re-engage passionately and make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sido, in her nightgown, carries an oil lamp down the corridor. From Colette’s bedroom comes the rhythmic creak of the bed springs that she does her best to ignore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aerial shot moves over the rooftops, churches, squares and streets of Paris. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT 52 Colette comes out of the kitchen eating a peach. A little BULLDOG comes scampering after her. This is Toby Chien. S hears an argument and moves stealthily through the apartm to ascertain its source. Through the door she sees Pierre Veber (angry) and Schwob (diplomatic) in front of Willy’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Get out! Both of you! This is harassment!

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Willy, come on. You’re not being fair.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: This is the third time I’ve had to come round and ask you for it!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Then stop coming round and bloody well asking!

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: I am close to being evicted. You owe me 400 francs. You’d get the advance from Ollendorff you said!  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 31.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And I will - by Friday.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: You said that last week.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: A factory needs to pay its workers, Willy!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Go on strike then! Get some other idiot to hire you! Leave me alone! Both of you! I’1l have your money by Friday.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: You'd better bloody have it! Veber walks briskly into the living room, nods to Colette too angry to speak, and exits. Schwob follows, saying goodbye. Willy emerges, forlorn, and starts to get ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Damn them! They’d never get published by themselves. I lend them my name, my reputation... I take all the risk. And there’s no money. We simply need more output.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You could get another writer in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And pay them with what? We only have about 1000 coming in this month - 300 from the Echo, 425 for the next vamp novel and 250 from the music reviews. But it doesn’t cover our outgoings.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: How can we spend that much?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: The mortgage, Matilde, restaurants...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You always pick up the bill, Willy, however many people join us.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s expected.  53 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 32.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And the casino. And the races...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do? Live like a monk? Or a peasant?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying we could economize. Mademoiselle Terrain always used to say, “Look after the pennies and..” Then lightning strikes...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You... You!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You could write them up. Those stories of Saint-Sauveur you told me last year. They could be Willy’s next novel.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: My school stories?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes. There may be something there...You must start straight away, my love. Aim for four hours at a time - the wolves are at the door! He goes back to his study. Colette’s mind is racing. INT. ENTRANCE ROOM — MOMENT’S LATER 53 Sitting at a desk, exercise book open, Colette dips her fountain pen in the ink. A statuette of Willy is perched the front of the desk, overlooking her. She writes SCHOOL NOTES BY GABRIELLE-SIDONIE COLETTE on the first page.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My name is Claudine. I live in... Montigny. I was born there in...1881. I shall probably not die there.  54 55 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 33. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - LATE 54

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: From directly above, we see Willy trudging upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later, a rather tipsy Willy enters the bedroom. Colette is in bed, her eyes wide open.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I only just stopped writing. Willy sits on the bed, belches, and takes off his boots.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Did you manage four hours...?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Twice that. At least.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Really?! You must be a natural!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’ve changed a few things...for the story. But it might ruffle a few feathers back home.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about the facts. You can add a character, make up an event. Adapt it to the times! All people really want is the feeling, the emotion - that great sweep of narrative.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: So I should just write what I want?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes! No one will ever dispute it - and if they do... “It is the hand that holds the pen that writes history.” Spontaneously, Colette comes over to him, wraps her arms around him from behind and nibbles on his ear. He doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You're not in the mood?  56 57 58 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 34.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’m tired as a bear in winter... Save it for the book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC STARTS UP. We see Colette label a new exercise book SCHOOL NOTES PART 3 before she starts on the fresh page.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “These are the copses, where bushes spitefully catch your face as you pass. Those are full of sun and strawberries and lilies-of-the-valley and...snakes. I’ve shuddered there with choking terror at the sight of those dreadful, smooth, cold bodies gliding in front of my feet.’ She is completely absorbed.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “I feel so much alone there, my eyes lost far away amongst the trees, in the green, mysterious daylight that is at once deliciously peaceful and a little unnerving because of the loneliness and the vague darkness.” INT. WILLY’S STUDY - MORNING 57 There’s a pile of five notebooks on Willy’s desk with a ribbon round them and a label that says “For Willy.” Seated behind his desk, Willy unties the precious package picks up the first book and settles in to read it. After a few pages he takes a cigar and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette is playing with TOBY CHIEN on the floor. She gets up and looks at the grandfather clock in the hall - 1:30.

dialogues.speaker: HALF AN HOUR LATER
dialogues.text: Willy emerges with the books. Colette is on the sofa with the dog, a novel open in front of her. He smiles, congratulatory but awkward.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?  59 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 35.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well... there we are. You did it. I take my hat off to you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s... beautiful. I spent the whole day in Saint-Sauveur.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You don’t like it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I do...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Truth?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes. The nature descriptions are... charming.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: “Charming...?” Willy heads off to boudoir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, perfectly charming! Sorry, I need to take a piss.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Nothing - really - it’s a truly wonderful depiction. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT —- BEDROOM 59 She follows him into the bedroom. He goes into the adjoin boudoir, takes out a chamber pot and starts pissing. She flops onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ..-And?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We won't be able to get it published is the shame of it...  60 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 36.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Honestly...? She nods. He takes a breath. WILLY (CONT’D) So...I’1l treat you like any other writer I’m giving a report to, shall

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Except I love you. I adore you. Let’s be clear about that.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Just tell me. He finishes up, zips up, and comes into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: There’s nothing driving it. No plot. A novel by Willy... It grips you from page one. Yours has... (he gestures) ...too many adjectives. Some of the characters are interesting but overall... Well, it’s just too cloying. Too...feminine. She says nothing, stares at the floor, anger mounting.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Well that was a waste of nine months.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Not if you enjoyed it. Not wanting to break in front of Willy, she storms off, through the apartment. INT. WILLY’S STUDY 60 Colette slams the door behind her, eyes brimming with tears. She opens the notebook and looks at the first page It says, “School Notes by Gabrielle-Sidonie Colette.” She takes a pen, crosses out her name.  61 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 37. And stops, leaving the single word “Colette.” She looks a it for a moment, tears in her eyes, and underlines it. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - MUSIC ROOM - EVENING 61 A makeshift stage, where the famous mime artist, WAGUE, performs a lip-sync sketch, accompanied by a PIANIST and FEMALE SINGER. The audience is transfixed by his mastery the form. Colette and Schwob are at the edge of the crowd. Colette dressed in black and white, her style feels modern and ed well ahead of the fussily-dressed socialites.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Wague’s mesmerizing, isn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Yes - he’s the king of cantomime... The song plays out its last few lines. Everyone bursts in applause.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Two champagne glasses are taken off a tray.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (to the servant) Thank you, Geraud.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Cheers. They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s it going with your book?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s gone. I tried but it wasn’t any good.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy hated it. I don’t care. I don’t need to leave a mark on this world. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give me a flock of starlings and that will intoxicate me. Something real. Not just doing lines for the headmaster.. (takes a moment) Did you always write, Schwob?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: I didn’t really have a choice. It was simply... There.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Does it make you happy?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Oh god no! I do it to prevent me from going mad. But sometimes, occasionally, it will transport me. This registers with Colette. Despite her bravura - she mi it. They are interrupted by a beautiful couple; GASTON an JEANNE de CAILLAVET.

dialogues.speaker: GASTON
dialogues.text: Hello Schwob! Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Hello Gaston, Jeanne. Do you know Colette?

dialogues.speaker: JEANNE
dialogues.text: I think we've been introduced but... I don’t remember that name.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s new - in a manner of speaking.

dialogues.speaker: JEANNE
dialogues.text: Well then, I will think of this as our first meeting. Schwob looks from one to the other, sensing a definite energy. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - ENTRY ROOM 62 Madame de Caillavet is demonstrating the newly installed LIGHT SWITCH to WILLY, who seems distracted.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: It’s so easy. On and off. No more sooty candles.  62a COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 39.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe one day they will do my building.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: It’s so much safer too. Even if the light is a little... bright.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Indeed. If you’1ll excuse me. Willy makes his exit and looks through the crowd for Colette. He rounds a corner and sees, through one room in which PEOPLE ARE DANCING, into a far room where Colette, GASTON and JEANNE DE CAILLAVET are sitting together. INT. MME. DE CAILLAVET’S SALON - SMOKING ROOM 62a The newly introduced friends are all already quite tipsy. They are sitting in front of a MIRRORED WALL that reflect the DANCERS. Gaston is reading Colette’s palm. As Willy stares, a flicker of jealousy passes through his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GASTON
dialogues.text: You have a long life line. Very strong head line - here. And your love line splits in three.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And what could that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JEANNE
dialogues.text: Who knows? Gaston laughs, somewhat flirtatiously.

dialogues.speaker: GASTON
dialogues.text: So many intersecting lines.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I have the hands of a man - see. She measures up to Gaston - hers are larger.

dialogues.speaker: JEANNE
dialogues.text: You have a touch of Hermes, Colette. There’s something androgynous about you.

dialogues.speaker: GASTON
dialogues.text: No, I know what it is. You’ve the soul of Narcissus! Filled with sensuality and bitterness.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 40.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: My soul is filled with beans and bacon rinds. You’1l find nothing else there. They all laugh. Willy arrives in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: GASTON DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: Willy, you ogre, how are you? We've been greatly enjoying the company of Colette - now she is no longer hiding her light under a bushel.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Quoting the good book, Gaston? You may remember a little verse about coveting other men’s wives.

dialogues.speaker: GASTON
dialogues.text: And you may remember one about not trying to remove a speck from your brother’s eye with a log in your own.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (amused) Touché Gaston. Your wits are improving... somewhat. We’d better go now, darling.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: His first play was absolute rubbish - but his mother runs a salon, so of course it was a huge success and he was praised to the skies for his brilliant “writing” and sublime “talent.” Unctuous prick... He was after you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy, he’s not that type. Besides they just got married.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: They’re no longer on honeymoon, my dear. Colette looks at him, slightly amused...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Your jealousy is misplaced.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Why so..?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 41.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It was actually his wife I found interesting.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Jeanne?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. Willy considers this. COLETTE (CONT’D) What would you think of that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s a different case.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Perhaps... Willy smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above we see two burly men ascending the staircase. 65 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - DAY - 1898 65 A knock at the door. Colette answers to two rough-looking bailiffs.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Good Morning, Ma’am. I need to speak to the gentleman of the house.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Monsieur Henri Gautier Villar - Is he in?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You can speak to me about whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Sorry ma’am. Willy walks up the hallway.  66 67 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 42.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Sir, I have a repossession order for two arm chairs, one armoire, one oak desk.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Do you have the court papers?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Here you are. All in order. Willy surveys them and resigned, steps to the side.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s only bits of wood. (to the Bailiffs) The chairs are in the front parlour. Armoire’s in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: With all my clothes in...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Clear it out! I’1l see to the desk. She storms off in exasperation. Willy goes into the offic INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - OFFICE 66 The desk is surrounded by piles of paper and envelopes. H clears the papers out of the second lowest drawer and ope the bottom drawer. Inside are a stack of school notebooks Colette’s novel. He picks them out of the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Take it! Take it away! He opens the book and flips through a few pages. Then a f more, his curiosity aroused. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - DAY 67 Willy sits on a single chair in the middle of the room. This time he’s engaged - gripped! He makes margin notes i spidery handwriting.  68 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 43.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (to himself) I am a bloody idiot. Then, he skips back to the first page where it says “Scho Notes by (crossing out) Colette.” He neatly rips out the page and screws it up. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - WILLY’S STUDY — NIGH In a pool of gaslight, Willy and Colette are seated at th desk. Willy is going through his notes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: ..-example, “it’s a lovely spring morning,” liven it up. How about: (grand gesture) “Perhaps it’s the season. It’s too fine - almost disgracefully fine.” She scribbles it down. WILLY (CONT’D) And page 29 - that scene with Luce. (he finds it) I’ve added: “she brushes up against me suggestively, her blue eyes half closed and her mouth half-open.”

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: That’s quite louche.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Louche sells, my dear. Trust me - all we need is a little more spice, a little less literature. I know what men want. And so do the publishers. Colette ponders this for a moment - not completely satisf

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And you really think they’1l take it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes! Ollendorff will go nuts for it.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (ironically) As you did on first reading.  69 70 71 72 73 74 75 75a

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well never mind about that now. We've got to work work work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The presses are rolling, pumping out copies of the novel. EXT. PRINTER’S COURTYARD - DAY 70 Crates of the book are being loaded onto a HORSE-DRAWN WAGON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOP CLERK builds the Claudine books onto a pyramid- shaped display. Behind is a sign: “CLAUDINE AT SCHOOL, BY WILLY.” INT. MADAME DE CAILLAVET’S SALON — DAY 73 Rachilde (the journalist) is reading her own review out loud to a crowd that includes Willy.

dialogues.speaker: RACHILDE
dialogues.text: ",..Claudine is a young girl froma small village, yet, she is all of us. Feisty, opinionated, selfish and sensual, she astounds us with her moxie, her desires and her crimes! The crowd let’s out an “Oooo.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Cousin Bette-type OLD MAID is in line with the book. In front of her, TWO SCHOOL GIRLS have purchased a copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG NANNY is reading the book, ignoring the CRYING BA in the perambulator beside her. EXT. CONVENT - DAY 75a A nun has abandoned her holy book to read Claudine.  76 77 78 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules watches, as Sido opens a package revealing the book

dialogues.speaker: JULES
dialogues.text: Look at that!

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: (critically) Yes, look at it... INT. SALON — DAY 77 Rachilde continues reading her rave review - to Willy.

dialogues.speaker: RACHILDE
dialogues.text: “It took an extraordinary man to define this modern young woman. Willy, your book will change the world.." (she raises a glass) To Claudine!

dialogues.speaker: SALON-GOERS
dialogues.text: To Claudine! Schwob and Colette watch from a corner.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: All Paris is saying your husband is a genius.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: He is, if that book is anything to go by. Colette smiles, indicates Willy with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Look at him. I haven’t seen him as happy for a long time. In the center of the room Willy is up on some FRIENDS shoulders, uncorking champagne. Colette gives Schwob a tight lipped smile. Something is rankling her but she won confess it - yet! MUSIC ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and OLLENDORFF, the publisher, are finishing up a meeting in OLLENDORFF’S double high book-lined office.  79

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Well, we’ve never had one fly off the shelves like this before. Quite a phenomenon. Everyone’s talking about it. And you know who’s buying it? Young women!
Really, I thought...that’s interesting.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: We've also been having enquiries about theatrical rights. Any thoughts?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of course, the theatre is the next logical step! With as large a stage as possible!

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: It’s the theatre-going public which will make you rich, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Make us all rich, my dear Ollendorff. They laugh as they leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette is waiting by a carriage outside. She and Ollendorff coming down the stairs, talking but can’t quite make out what they are saying.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: So what size are you thinking of..?

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Perhaps - 20,000 units or 25,000 somewhere in that ballpark. I’m waiting to see what the pre-orders are like back from the sellers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And what kind of return would that yield?

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Well, we’re calculating about 3 francs a unit profit - so, yes - it’s a tidy sum. 79 sees Willy business, The men push through the double doors and are now fully audible.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 47.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mme. Willy, a great honor.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Listen! Claudine At School is heading for her third printing.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: I believe that Willy based “Claudine” in part on your school days?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe I had a little something to contribute. Ollendorff chuckles. Willy’s smile is stretched thin.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Well, I’m very glad your experiences have borne such wonderful fruit. Very nice to meet you, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy climbs in next to Colette.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Gare de Lyon.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Where’re we going?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER 81
dialogues.text: Willy is uncharacteristically quiet.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What do you think is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What. .?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 48.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Finally...finally we’ve a success. And then you imply that I’m not the true author of it.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I didn’t... Most books are “based on” something.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Listen, we’re holding dynamite here. We have created something very powerful. But if it goes off at the wrong time it will blow our bloody heads off.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It was only Ollendorff. He’s your publisher, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Schwob also said something.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Schwob’s part of the factory.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: People love to talk. They’1l praise you to your face, but as soon as you turn around...Tch! The knives are in your back. You don’t know the mentality here. I do.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I know it well enough to write a book that’s the toast of Paris.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Shout it to the streets then. Tell people. Roll up for the massacre... Colette sighs, Willy really is quite upset. The matter seems to cut to the core of his identity. WILLY (CONT’D) I’m sorry. Perhaps I overreacted... Anyway, I’ve a surprise for you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Then it wouldn’t be a surprise... We're going to the country. Colette smiles, puts her head on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Good. This city is driving me mad. 82 EXT. FOREST — DAY 82 Colette and Willy walk through trees, holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What’s that one?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Lime.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And that one?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Douglas Fir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And that one?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Chestnut...A weeping Chestnut.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you love nature so much. Animals are vile to each other.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Animals are honest at least. They never lie.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well yes, my dear, that is because they can’t speak. They come out of the trees into a clearing. There is a small lawn in front of a neoclassical country home. WILLY (CONT’D) Look at that!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s somebody's house.  83 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 50.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Wonder who lives there.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’m thirsty. Let’s see if they'll stand us a drink. He marches towards the house. She follows.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy, they might shoot at us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Colette stand at the door. He knocks and rings bell. He waits a moment then rings again.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Wait... they might be upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Or deaf... They’ve been deafened by all the country silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Shhh... I thought I heard something.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Give me a kiss. Willy is on good form and charming Colette. She kisses hi aware too that the door might open.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Someone might come.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Good... He tries the door, it’s locked. Kisses her again. WILLY (CONT’D) Put your hand in my pocket. There’s something there for you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy! He leads her hand downward. Slightly puzzled, Colette reaches into Willy’s pocket and retrieves... a key!  84

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Allow me. 51. Willy takes the key, puts it in the lock and turns it. Th lock springs open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 They enter the formerly-grand old house - still beautiful but dilapidated. The rooms glow luminous in the last of t sun.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ...-Whose house is it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: For you, my love, my heart. Lest Paris drive you mad.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s yours. You’re always talking about missing the countryside. Willy kisses the key and gives it to Colette him and then again at the house.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy, I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Somewhere for you to write. And be Colette hugs him lovingly, then breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: So...where did you get the money?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I got an advance from Ollendorff. 25,000 Francs.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: For the next book. “Claudine in Paris.” who stares at alone.  85 85a 86 88 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 52.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?! I can’t do another Claudine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Just write about us! Our lives! Our friends! Change the names. Create gossip!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We'll talk about the details later. (he looks up at the house) So...do you like it? Colette takes in the house’s impressive dimensions.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s indescribable.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No such word. A good writer should be able to describe anything no matter what. INT. COUNTRY HOUSE — LIVING ROOM — DAY 85 Inside, WORKERS are scraping the paint off the living roo floor. The room is unfurnished with peeling wallpaper. INT. COUNTRY HOUSE 85a Two workers carry in a sofa. Colette follows carrying a c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette digs a wild patch of garden. She is sweaty and co in earth but hugely exhausted and content. She plants car turnips and sweet pea shoots below their sticks. In the background, we see the hoops of an OUTDOOR GYM. INT. COUNTRY HOUSE — LIVING ROOM — DAY 88 Colette watches from the window as a carriage pulls into the driveway. The floors are now polished, the wallpaper redone, the place fully furnished.  89 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 53.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: This is it? Your total output for all these weeks? Willy stands, holding a few manuscript pages.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I had to do the house - all the repairs. The painting, the tiling...pruning the roses.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Bugger the roses. We have a deadline.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s actually harder to write out here... Alone. And I don’t want to write another Claudine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? Claudine is a franchise! Do you realize how rare this moment is? When people are begging for more? Come. He walks her through the house and up the stairs. WILLY (CONT’D) What would the headmaster do if Claudine had not done her homework?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy. Don’t be silly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (serious) What would he do?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Make her do lines? Put her over his knee and tan her hide?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Correct. He arrives at the door of the study and stands expectantl at the door jamb as she walks past him into the study.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I‘1l start tomorrow.  90 91 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 54. But Willy closes the door and turns the key in the lock. COLETTE (CONT’D) No! Willy!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Write!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy!!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You will do as I say! I will return in four hours and I expect to see pages. He pockets the key and goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustrated, she tries the door handle. It’s locked.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy!! This isn’t funny. She bangs on the door, anger building. COLETTE (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: LET ME OUT
dialogues.text: (kicks the door.) Bastard...absolute...arrogant bastard! I’1l write the bloody book! And I‘’11 tell them it was me! Me! Me who wrote it! Bastard! I‘11 tell them! Claudine is mine! Mine! She stands back breathing hard. Then turns with a look of resignation to the writing desk.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: She sits for a moment, still smarting from the exchange, her pen in the ink and writes “Claudine in Paris.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a book - CLAUDINE IN PARIS It is revealed as part of a HUGE shop display. A LARGE SI announces “THE LATEST NOVEL FROM WILLY.” In front of it i a large pyramid of books. MUSIC ENDS  92 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful day, PARISIANS are promenading and riding bicycles and velocipedes in the open air. Colette and Wil are pedaling a tandem. She’s at the front, putting in mos the leg work, he, true to form, is taking it easy at the back. Under the trees, a cafe has been set up with delicate fol chairs and small round tables. A few dozen SOCIETY TYPES enjoying tea and cakes. Depositing their tandem by a tree. Colette and Willy approach. There is a feeling that all eyes are on them. Walking through the tables they go past a beautiful red-h heiress, named GEORGIE Raoul Duval. She is taking tea wit companion, a pretty young girl named LILY.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Colette and Willy are here!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: So they are. Don’t stare. Across the patio, Colette and Willy are seated by a WAITE Georgie takes out a small card and scribbles a note.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go take this to them.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Post-exercise the couple are eating cake.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Mmmm. It’s good.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Indeed. He looks round. WILLY (CONT’D) How many people here do you think are reading Claudine in Paris - right now?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 56.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: At least three quarters, I'd say. And those who haven’t yet will soon catch up. He notices Lily weaving through the tables towards them. WILLY (CONT’D) (to himself) What comes this way?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: M. Willy, Mme. Colette, I have a note for you....from Mrs. Raoul Duval. Clearly a little starstruck, she hands Willy the note and surveys it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (remembering) Mrs. Raoul Duval. Georgie Raoul Duval?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh... wonderful!.. Please go tell your mistress we accept her invitation and look forward to her delightful company.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (thrilled) I will! And off she goes.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) ..-An American - a wayward debutante from Louisiana... she married a munitions magnate three times her age.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: They sound a bit dull.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: He is. She is anything but. (glances at her) We don’t have to...  93 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 57.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. Let’s go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the high ceilinged cafe, we follow a WAITER who drops bill off at a table where Georgie and Colette are in fits hysterics - the kind of laughter sustained by the serious drunk and flirtatious. Willy is providing the after-dinne entertainment. Lily sits by them, awed at getting to spen time with such celebrities, autograph book at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (almost crying with laughter) That’s so funny. Did he really say that?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Oh yes - he would. He is such a colossal snob.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Then Mme de Caillavet happened to mention that he was only a baron and not a Marquise. “Allow me, he said “I am also Duke of Anjou, Bishop of Coutances, Prince of Joinville, of Asturias, of Orléans and the Dunes. But all that isn't of the slightest importance... (with perfect timing) ..-here.” Everyone howls with laughter. A stray curl of her hair falls down over Georgie’s face.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Wait a moment. Colette takes the lock and tries to pat it back into plac A moment of electricity passes between the two. Willy watches fascinated. COLETTE (CONT’D) Hold still. That’s it. She takes her hands away. The disobedient lock immediatel falls back down. The women lose it. The waiter comes back by the table.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (paying the bill) Here you are.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 58.
