dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Monsieur Willy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Is the evening over already? I can’t bear it... (turning to her assistant) Lily, go tell the coachman to ready the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Of course... Lily doesn’t get up though.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Well..?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Ma’am but... (thrusting an autograph book forward) M. Willy, may I have your autograph..?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of course! My pleasure. I’1l even do you a doodle. Of me.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Oh thank you! He hands it back. Georgie looks impatient.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And yours too Madame Colette.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Oh come now...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Not at all. Spirit should always be rewarded. She returns the book to Lily who positively vibrates with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Good night, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Good night! She hurries off.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 59.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Well... I live at 74 Rue Goethe. If you’d like to stop by for at nightcap... The question hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. But I feel like I will retire this evening.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure now?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We'll play again soon, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Yes...I hope so. Before my bore of a husband returns. Well adieu! And she’s gone. Willy weighs this.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to go?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: The invitation was clearly for you. This really lands for Colette.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ++. Should I?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You don’t mind?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I'd be a hypocrite if I did, wouldn't I? Colette considers this. WILLY (CONT’D) If it’s any comfort to you, I will be at home lying in bed, thinking of the two of you in the fondest way possible.  94 95 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 60. INT. GEORGIE’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - NIGHT 94 Colette slowly ascends the dark staircase. Hiding her nervousness and her excitement. She knocks on the door. A a moment’s waiting Georgie answers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Come in. INT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 95 Georgie’s apartment, naturally, is very stylish.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What a nice place.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. This is my little pied-a-tere. Frederick is not so keen on the Art Nouveau pieces. But I love nature...and women. Colette looks at a painting of nymphs bathing.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I remember in Claudine At School when the girls go swimming together at night...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Night is the best time to swim.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: When I was a girl, I was told all the lakes in Louisiana have alligators. So I never went for a midnight swim but I regret it... Georgie looks down then raises her eyes towards Colette.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: When you raise your eyelids, it’s as if you were taking off all my clothes. Georgie looks down, blushing. COLETTE (CONT’D) Don’t look away. Look at me. Look at me looking at you. She does. It’s electric. Colette slowly moves in and kisses her for a long hot moment.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 61.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You have the most beautiful teeth. She indicates Colette’s slightly angled front canine.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Like an alligator. They smile and kiss again. 96 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - MORNING 96 Willy is perusing the morning mail. He hears the sound of entering and, affecting nonchalance, carries on reading. Colette enters, also acting cool.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My dear...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Have you fed Toby Chien?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I forgot. I thought Matilde does it. She heads down the hallway towards the kitchen. He stops with a question. WILLY (CONT’D) How was last night?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It was..interesting.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What do you think happened?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ah... well don’t tell me. I‘11 wait to read about it. When Claudine develops tender feelings towards a lady friend. Colette rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I won’t be writing it down.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: But you must... It’s prime material!  97 97a COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 62.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No! She heads out.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Will you see her again?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (calling out) Probably. Willy is somewhat unsettled by his wife’s casualness and. independence. INT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - DAY 97 As Georgie is finishing up her morning toilet, there’s th ring of a doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (murmurs ) One moment, my darling. She hastily wraps herself in a gown and makes her way thr the apartment. As she opens the door she is taken a back to see the bald pate of Monsieur Willy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Wonderful, you’re here.. I was just passing by...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Yes... He continues to stare at her. She flushes slightly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You'd better come in. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - ENTRANCE ROOM - 97a

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Colette is working away in her small room. The front door goes and Willy comes in.  98 99 100 101 102 103 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 63.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: How’s the writing going?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Slow...painful... How was your meeting with the bank?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Good... yes, it was good. I won't bore you with the details. He heads off. She continues writing. EXT. GEORGIE’S STREET - AFTERNOON 98 MUSIC COMES UP. A carriage pulls up outside the beautiful residence. Colette gets out and surveys it. INT. GEORGIE’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - DAY 99 Colette approaches the door and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Is she in?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes, please come in. Lily leaves as Colette enters. Inside, Colette turns towa Georgie’s bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s expecting you. Lily gives Colette a smile and leaves discreetly. EXT. GEORGIE’S STREET - EVENING 100 A carriage pulls up - but this time it’s Willy who gets out. INT. GEORGIE’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - EVENING 101 Willy approaches the door. Georgie opens it. He takes off his top hat and hands it to her as he goes in. INT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - DAY 102 Colette and Georgie make mad passionate love. INT GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - EVENING 103 Now Georgie is making love to Willy - with equal fervor.  103a 103b 104 105 106 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 64. INT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 103a Colette and Georgie;s passion continues to heat up... INT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - AFTERNOON 103b Georgie and Willy come to climax. EXT. GEORGIE’S STREET - AFTERNOON 104 Colette walks down the street looks up at the apartment. Someone who looks suspiciously like Willy is at the windo INT. GEORGIE’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - AFTERNOON 105 Colette marches up the stairs, rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Georgie! I know you’re in there. Still no answer. Colette knocks hard on the door. COLETTE (CONT’D) Georgie. Open up! More loud knocks. Eventually Georgie answers in a nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Colette, I was taking a nap. Colette pushes past her.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Who’s been in here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: No one. What are you doing? Colette looks to the bedroom where tell-tale cigar smoke hangs in layers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette is writing at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Blue cigar smoke feted the air... (she pauses, crosses out, then continues) I marched in and looked straight in the face of the Renaud. He recoiled, saying, “It was wicked of me. I’m sorry.”  107 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 65. Colette looks at the statue of Willy on her desk, wistfully.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rezi was there, of course she was there - covering herself up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette and Willy’s voices merge as the story transfers over.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: ..-I shall always remember her lily white face decomposing, as if it were dying right under my gaze. Once again at the desk under the circle of light, Willy i reading aloud from the notebooks, giving his customary polish to the latest Claudine. Colette sits quietly by as this chapter of their own lives is read. But she has more confidence now - more poise. She is growing into herself. He sets the book down. A moment’s thought. WILLY (CONT’D) It’s good.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I'd suggest you change the line when Renaud says, “It was wicked of me to do it.” But I know that you won’t.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (piqued) What do you think Renaud would say, in those circumstances?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Hmmm...something like, “Why...we were waiting for you, my dear.”

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t think she would believe him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of course not. This is a sore point.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 66. WILLY (CONT’D) But don’t you think she’s being hypocritical - I mean, it’s acceptable for Claudine to sleep with Rezi but she doesn’t want Renaud to do the same?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Not behind her back, no. The betrayal came when Renaud lied to her. Renaud who swore he would always be honest.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Perhaps he wanted to tell her, but he was frightened of her terrible jealousy?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Then he was a coward as well as a liar.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You’re very harsh on him.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Who else will be? And Renaud would never be jealous? If for instance, Claudine went off with.. A young man, for a change?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: He would find that unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Infidelity, for Renaud is a matter of gender.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It is... (clears his throat) How long have you known..?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: For a month or so. Colette has won this one. Willy clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well I must say, I’m impressed with the way you’ve handled yourself. The younger Claudine would have thrown a fit.  108 109 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 67.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m planning on killing Renaud off in the next one.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No - you can’t. Please.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (quoting Willy) “The hand that holds the pen writes history.” Willy shoots her an amused but slightly threatened look.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Renaud’s moral shadings aside, the writing is very good. Quite a work of art. Those little scratches you make on the paper - (he indicates) - very powerful. And it will have a powerful effect. Everyone will immediately know whom it’s about, there will be a huge scandal, the books will spread like thistledown all over France.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And M. Willy will have yet another hot book on his hands. An uneasy truce has been declared. WILLY (cont'd) You know what? I’m tempted to go back and put even more Georgie into Rezi.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy, we have to draw the line somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Why, my dear? Our marriage is already public domain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC COMES UP: The pages of the new novel fly rapidly ou the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ollendorff hands a brand new hardback copy of “Claudine e Menage by Willy” to Willy who nods approvingly.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 68. 110 INT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - DAY 110 Georgie pours a glass of brandy for Colette. She is clear wound up but trying to remain civilized.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: My husband - he’s just...pure rage. He was going to challenge Willy to a duel...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I’ve put him off. Hopefully it won’t come to that. (she looks at Colette) You've read it, yes?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: How worried should I be? Georgie walks across to her with the drink.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: The names have all been changed. It’s not blatantly obvious who is who...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. Everyone is chattering about it - saying it will be salacious in the extreme. (She clears her throat) I know you have no time for me since our separation and I know I behaved badly. But I’m begging you... Ask Willy to change it - before publication? Colette slowly shakes her head. GEORGIE (CONT’D) Please Colette... One woman to another? Please...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No, I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You’d let me suffer?  111 112 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 69.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s not just Willy, Georgie, it’s... the book itself...Willy thinks it’s a work of art. Georgie downs her drink and switches gears - no more tear a hardness comes to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You had your chance to be decent. So, it will be left to my husband to settle it. Ollendorff has agreed to a lump sum for the destruction of the entire print run.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What? You can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: He has already accepted.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: The sly bastard. You can’t. You just can’t.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: We have. And that is how it is. Colette finally snaps.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You are a duplicitous bitch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I had a good teacher. Colette leaves slamming the door. Georgie looks after her EXT. GEORGIE’S APARTMENT - DAY 111 Colette leaves the house in a rage. EXT. PRINTER’S COURTYARD - DAY 112 A WORKER pours petrol on a bonfire of novels then throws his cigarette butt on it to ignite the pile. It bursts in flame immediately. Charred pages rise with the heat. The worker takes another crate and dumps them on.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette and Willy are with Schwob in their favorite dinin spot feasting on oysters and champagne. There is an unexpected air of celebration.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Like a true French heroine, our daughter was burnt at the stake.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I said it would be a “hot book.”

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: The thing is though, Ollendorff signed the deal but unfortunately failed to mention... (drum rolls the table...) That he didn’t own the copyright. I do.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Unbelievable!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: All I had to do was trot round to another publisher and collect a second advance. The presses are hard at it as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: How do you two do it?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I think we got very lucky...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Not at all! That American tart and her senile lackey didn’t stand a chance. We are with the times! The wind is under our wings! And I have a little plan that will make Claudine the most popular girl in France, if not the entire world.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: With the play?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Not just that. We’1ll have Claudine perfume, Claudine lingerie, Claudine soap.  114 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 71.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: She will literally be a household name. They all laugh. INT. THEATRE — DAY - 1903 114 On a blackboard, in chalk is written “CLAUDINE AUDITIONS. An insipid actress is cooing her way though the dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: INSIPID ACTRESS
dialogues.text: My name is Claudine. I live in Montigny. I was born there in 1881. I shall probably not die there... Colette and Willy are sitting in the tenth row of the the In front of them are the DIRECTOR and two FINANCIERS. Colette, now in her late twenties, seems to have grown comfortable in her skin. Willy, on the other hand, is sho the tell-tale signs of a life too-well lived.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: She’s not bad.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: She’s terrible.

dialogues.speaker: INSIPID ACTRESS
dialogues.text: Montigny is a village, not a town: its streets, thank heaven, are not paved; the showers roll down them in little torrents that dry up in a couple hours; it is a village, not even a very pretty village, but, all the same, I adore it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (to Colette) Yes, you’re right. (shouts ) Thank you very much. Next. A SECOND ACTRESS comes up on stage and starts repeating t line. Colette notices the impressive hourglass silhouette of a woman in the rear doorway. The woman marches down the aisle and plants herself in front of them. Wearing a schoolgirl smock, she is vibrant Algerian, with bobbed hair and a tiny waist. This is POLAIRE.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 72.

dialogues.speaker: POLAIRE
dialogues.text: M. Willy. I am the real Claudine! Colette and Willy exchange an intrigued look.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: POLAIRE
dialogues.text: Me? My name is...Polaire! 115 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DA Colette and Willy sit, examining photographs of Polaire.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Polaire! Polaire! Daughter of the desert. Look at her! Look at her! She knows the role instinctively.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: She talks about the book as though it were a religion.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: A “Sister of Perpetual Claudine.”

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s interesting. She’s started to copy little gestures and mannerisms that I do.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Do you think I could act?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You? No. It would be a criminal waste.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Waste of what? Willy shrugs, dismissing the thought. He picks up a photo and examines it closer. WILLY (cont'd) That bobbed hair... I’ve never seen anything like it. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (suspicious) I always imagined Claudine had long hair.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 73.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: That was the 19th Century Claudine...this is now. He holds the picture up beside her. WILLY (CONT’D) Would look good on you, actually. Very fetching.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. Willy, I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It would make you look younger.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You’re turning thirty soon - what better time to turn the clocks...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Thank you... But I’ve always had my hair... Sido would kill me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Just think of it... You and Polaire - The Claudine Twins!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’ll be a goldmine of publicity. All Paris will be atwitter.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No! Never... in a thousand years. 116 INT. HAIR SALON — DAY 116 Scissors hack through thick long tresses. A HAIRDRESSER shows Colette her new bob in a mirror that reflects the back. Colette gives a prim, uptight nod. 117 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM — EV Colette enters the room shorn. The haircut looks awkward it hasn’t quite settled in yet. Willy looks up from his newspaper and stares at her amazed.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 74.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My word! Where have you gone?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy, I hate it. Willy circles his strange new wife.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No... I like it very much.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s absurd. My head looks too big for my body.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’ll just take a bit of getting used to... Colette goes to a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Oh — what did I do? Colette covers her face with her hands. She starts to hyperventilate, holding back sobs. COLETTE (CONT’D) She butchered me. I look ten years older. You made me do this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh come now, you went along with it... you always do. Unexpectedly, she flies at him. He holds her arms away fr his chest. As they struggle -

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You bastard! Look at me...and all for your damned publicity?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Gabrielle!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You crowd-pleaser! You cheap bastard!! You shit! She starts beating on his chest. And keeps going... until she is exhausted and breaks into tears.  118 119 120 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poster announces “CLAUDINE IN PARIS — TONIGHT” as CROWD make their way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starting on the back of Colette’s head, now looking super chic with the new haircut, we follow Colette and Willy as they take their seats in a private box for the opening night of "Claudine." Next to them are SALONITE and her husband.

dialogues.speaker: SALONITE
dialogues.text: Colette, you look ravishing. She smiles. The house lights dim, the ORCHESTRA strikes up and the curtain goes up. Polaire makes an exuberant entrance.

dialogues.speaker: POLAIRE
dialogues.text: My name is Claudine. I live in Montigny... Colette’s eyes shine as her heroine becomes flesh. POLAIRE (CONT’D) .-.I was born there in 1881. I shall probably not die there. Montigny is a village, not a town: its streets, thank heaven, are not paved; the showers roll down them in little torrents that dry up in a couple hours; it is a village, not even a very pretty village, but, all the same, I adore it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An air of celebration - champagne and music. At the far e of the room is Willy, sitting on a throne, holding court with Colette and Schwob by him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I thought of all my novels, this was the one that would translate to theatre.

dialogues.speaker: MME. DE CAILLAVET
dialogues.text: I have to give it to you, Willy. It’s going to be a huge success - enjoy your moment of triumph.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 76.

dialogues.speaker: VEBER
dialogues.text: Now that you are such a celebrity, you’1l become more insufferable than ever.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: That’s the plan, Veber! That’s the plan! Willy continues to hold forth. Someone who appears to be a dapper gentleman dressed as Napoleon approaches Colette. This, we will find out momentarily, is a woman called MISSY.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Can you believe this crowd? Everyone’s here! Look there’s the Marquise de Belbeuf... or Missy, as she’s known.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: A woman?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Descended from Empress Josephine on one side, the Tsar of Russia on the other - She only shows up for very special occasions.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Fascinating. The moment is interrupted by a hubbub. Colette looks arou the corner where Polaire is making her entrance carried aloft on a litter by FOUR MUSCULAR GUYS. She is showered with praise and flowers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Polaire! Over here!

dialogues.speaker: POLAIRE
dialogues.text: Monsieur Willy! She is deposited before... POLAIRE (CONT’D) How was it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Brilliant, my dear! You were perfection!

dialogues.speaker: POLAIRE
dialogues.text: Thank you, M. Willy! Colette?  121 122 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 77. She looks to Colette who raises her glass.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You are her. The living Claudine. Polaire is so excited she physically vibrates.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Polaire, alight upon my knee... He pats his knee and she sits. WILLY (CONT’D) And you Tetette! He grabs her by the hand.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Come here! She acquiesces and lands on his other knee. Willy is now framed by two “Claudines” with perfect bobbed hair. He waves to a photographer. WILLY (CONT’D) Here we have the Claudine Trinity. The father... (he indicates himself) The mother... (he indicates Colette) And the daughter... (Polaire)

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Hold still! A magnesium flash goes off, freezing the picture. MUSIC comes up. A MONTAGE SHOWS WILLY’S HIGHLY INNOVATIVE EXPLOITATION OF THE CLAUDINE PHENOMENON.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PHOTO SESSION
dialogues.text: Camera flashes capture Colette, Willy and Polaire ina series of poses. Colette plays it coy - kneeling at his feet, batting her eyes at him, sketching him. She has certainly adopted the Claudine persona full tilt. INTERCU WITH...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER HEADLINES 122
dialogues.text: “CLAUDINE SENSATION” “MENAGE A TROIS” “VIVE CLAUDINE”  123 124 124a 124b 124c 125 126 126a 126b 127 127a 127b COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 78.

dialogues.speaker: POSTER 123
dialogues.text: It says “Do Not Go and See CLAUDINE IN PARIS - it’s immoral.”

dialogues.speaker: MAGAZINE HEADLINE 124
dialogues.text: “THE YEAR OF CLAUDINE!” INT. STREET - DAY 124a A MIDDLE AGED MAN reads a newspaper with the headline MEN A TROIS. INT. SHELF/MAGAZINE RACK 124b Pan along several CLAUDINE magazines - ending on one that says VIVE CLAUDINE. INT. BATHROOM 124c A YOUNG WOMAN picks a bottle of Claudine perfume and appl a few squirts. INT. HAIR SALON — DAY 125 A number of WOMEN, including a couple of SALONITES, getti their hair bobbed to look like Claudine.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 126
dialogues.text: INT. SHELF/BEAUTY PARLOR 126a A shelf full of jars selling CLAUDINE FACE CREAM. INT. BOIS DE BOULOGNE PARK - DAY 126b A line of WOMEN fanning themselves with CLAUDINE FANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCHOOL GIRLS gaze at MANNEQUINS — all dressed "A la Claudine." EXT. COURTYARD - DAY 127a A ROUGH HANDSOME WORKER takes a CLAUDINE Cigarette from t packet with his mouth and lights it. INT. SHELF/CONFECTIONERS 127b Boxes of CLAUDINE CANDIES fill the self.  127c 127d 128 128a 128b 129 129a 129b 130 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 79. EXT. BOIS DE BOULOGNE - DAY 127c A YOUNG BUSINESSMAN reads a paper that says CLAUDINE SENSATION while a YOUNG WOMAN reads a magazine that says SECRET DE CLAUDINE. EXT. STREET 127d Children eat CLAUDINE CANDIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN dresses in CLAUDINE LINGERIE. INT. BEDROOM - DAY 128a A young DANDY slicks his hair with CLAUDINE HAIR OIL. INT. BATHROOM 128b A WOMAN reaches out to pick up a bar of CLAUDINE SOAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUNDLE OF NEWSPAPERS lands with the headline “EPOCH DE CLAUDINE.” INT. BEDROOM 129a TWO YOUNG GIRLS play with CLAUDINE DOLLS. EXT. BOIS DE BOULOGNE - DAY 129b A group of YOUNG LADS trade CLAUDINE postcards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The assembled (including Veber, Schwob, Polaire) bang rhythmically on the table with glasses, cutlery, and fist as Willy stands at the head of a large table improvising poem. Missy sits far down the table near Colette’s end with a SUFFRAGETTE FRIEND.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Claudine, she is a Midas Minx. Her smile mysterious as a sphinx. She walks and talks, she laughs - she thinks! Claudine, Claudine, Claudine... He starts to move to the rhythm, swaying from side to sid WILLY (CONT’D) Claudine’s a girl that knows no bounds. A fox that’s never caught by hounds. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Exploding star that makes no sound! Claudine, Claudine, Claudine! Willy beckons a few YOUNG WOMEN up from the table and the link arms forming an impromptu can-can line. The rhythm speeds up and intensifies... WILLY (CONT’D) Who is this girl in my heart? (ALL: CLAUDINE! )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who has been there from the start? (ALL: CLAUDINE! )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who is a bit of a tart? (ALL: CLAUDINE)

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDINE
dialogues.text: The merriment in the room is sky high. WILLY (CONT’D) Who is the one I admire? (ALL: CLAUDINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is the queen of desire? (ALL: CLAUDINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who has set Paris on fire? (ALL: CLAUDINE)

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDINE
dialogues.text: The Marquise scribbles something on a card and passes it Colette via her friend and then Wague. Colette looks at t card. It has the family coat of arms and says, “Let’s mee WILLY (CONT’D) Who's wearing a school girl’s smock? (CLAUDINE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's causing a hell of a shock? (CLAUDINE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who working it all round the clock? (CLAUDINE )

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDINE
dialogues.text: He raises his hand, slightly out of breath, to quiet the banging, for a more personal last verse that he delivers straight to Colette. WILLY (CONT’D) And in a dream, I find myself, Next to Claudine, And her magical eyes, Forgetting all other music For the laughter of her voice... He raises his glass. Everyone follows.  131 132 133 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 81. WILLY (CONT’D) To Claudine!

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDINE
dialogues.text: Colette and Willy’s eyes connect, sharing a moment of tri INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - NIGHT 131 Colette and Willy enter laughing, giddy with champagne, a turn on the light. The apartment has been considerably

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Me too. There’s more steps everyday. But what a night! We have Paris in the palm of our hand. They laugh. Then Colette switches on the light and notice something - a Claudine dress laid out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy..?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My dear. I wondered if tonight you would... (he indicates the dress) It would help me. They look at each other, the bed - and the dress - betwee them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette puts on the dress and looks at herself uneasily i the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She re-enters the dimly-lit room. Willy waits in bed. Colette walks across the room and stands in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My love. Still seated, he pulls her into him, nuzzling into her bosom.  134 135 136 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 82. WILLY (CONT’D) Oh yes, my love...my Claudine. Colette stares ahead into the blackness with a mixture of sadness, tenderness, confusion and pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot day in Paris. Heat rises up, making the street look like it is in an impressionist painting. A YOUNG WOMAN in Claudine outfit, heads towards the apartment. It’s a simi view to scene 38 when Colette walked towards the house, b now, there are motor cars mixed in with the horse drawn carriages. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT —- STAIRCASE -— DAY 13 The young woman ascends the stairs. ANOTHER YOUNG WOMAN, dressed a la Claudine, is going down the other way. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DAY 13 The gramophone is playing. Colette is having cheese and wine with a friend - Wague, the mime artist from the salo

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Here try this Soumaintrain. (he takes a slice) It reminds me of Saint Sauveur.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, delicious.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: When are you going on tour?

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: A few weeks. Some real flea pits too. It’ll be hell.. Again.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Why do you do it then? The front door bell goes off.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: I’m addicted. I love every single dive and wastrel. You should come with us.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I can’t do cantomime.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 83.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: This isn’t cantomime this is a new kind of pantomime. Pure action - the right gesture is worth a thousand words. This registers with Colette. The bell rings again. She looks towards Willy's office to see a seated figure on th phone. (This is PAUL HEON whom we will soon meet.)

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: Willy Gauthier Villars residence... He’s busy right now can I take a message?... yes...yes...Would you like to make an appointment?...how about next Tuesday?.. He maybe has some time the following Thursday... You can’t make that either... Yes, the Wednesday after is clear... I’1l put you down for half an hour... What’s your name? How do you spell that? Good. Look forward to seeing you a week on Wednesday... I’1l tell him. ..Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette goes to answer the door and there stands a 23 yea old young woman done up a la Claudine. This is MEG.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Is Monsieur Willy at home? I was hoping he could sign my book.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Follow me. Colette walks into the living room and calls. COLETTE (CONT’D) Héon! Another one. Outside Willy's office the newly appointed Afro-Caribbean secretary, PAUL HEON, hangs up the phone.  138 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 84.

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: This way please. Meg walks towards Willy’s Office.

dialogues.speaker: HEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go right in... INT. WILLY’S STUDY - DAY 138 The door is ajar. The girl sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Monsieur Willy...? He looks up from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I am he.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Hello, I was wondering if you would sign this. She produces a copy of "Claudine at School."

dialogues.speaker: MEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s my favorite book.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. To whom shall I inscribe it?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: My name is Meg... I am the real Claudine. Willy looks up at her, attracted by her youth and beauty.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (dropping her “Claudine” voice) I’m from London.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Wonderful! And how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I’m older than I look actually. I’m twenty three.  139 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 85.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I’m younger than I look - I'm forty six.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: (resuming Claudine voice) I don’t mind. He hands the book back.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well here you are...

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Thank you, this will be my prize possession. And that was Mme. Colette I met at the door?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It would be strange if it wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: She’s so beautiful - her eyes! So much depth - and maturity. She gives Willy a knowing smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a quiet lane away from the crowds, Colette and Missy walk Toby Chien. The Marquise is very affable but also a little reserved - like a polite gentleman of the day.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Look lilies...

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Yes, calla palustris.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: There’s not many people in Paris who would know their proper name.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: My maternal grandfather was a botanist. He was always away - collecting samples down in the tropics.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: My maternal grandfather spent time in the tropics too. He was a quadroon.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 86.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, from Martinique. Missy raises an approving eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Wonderful. Two young women walk by dressed as Claudines, giggling. MISSY (CONT’D) Congratulations, by the way. It seems that Claudines are everywhere these days.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes... There’s even been a Claudine murderess - in Marseilles. She slit her husband’s throat.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Good for her. Colette can’t help but smile. MISSY (CONT’D) But seriously, you’ve done something important. You’ve invented a type.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You mean Willy has.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I mean you have. All the young girls between girlhood and womanhood - you give them a voice. Colette says nothing. A force of personality is breaking through Missy’s reserve... MISSY (CONT’D) You should own up to it.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Someone told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 141 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 87.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Didn’t need to be told. Meeting you was enough. You are a force of nature.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s true I...I wrote them. It’s just...

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I know... It’s a man’s world. They exchange a look. Ahead of them is a more populated thoroughfare. They hover for a moment, in the shade of th last tree, cherishing their improvised privacy. Colette kisses her fingers and places them on Missy’s lips as a carriage goes rattling past. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - DAY 139A Colette is composing a note at her small writing desk.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hope the path we walked today was merely the beginning... I see your face, Missy.. strong, vulnerable. I've never met anyone like you - polite yet direct, reserved yet brave - a true gentle man. I will think of you, if I may, as my chevalier. She smiles to herself as she writes - Missy has really go to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC COMES UP. An AERIAL SHOT glides over the fields, hedges and forests of the French countryside. A very early automobile is putt-putting down the road. Willy is driving, with Meg seated by his side. In the bac Colette sits next to Missy. EXT. COLETTE’S COUNTRY HOUSE - DAY 141 Meg and Missy are throwing a ball for Toby Chien down the lawn. Willy and Colette are left alone on the veranda amidst the rubble of a picnic.  142 143 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 88.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Meg's a sweet thing, isn’t she? She can be a little overeager, but there we are...she reminds me of you - ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Nothing like. But she is very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We do have a very modern marriage, don’t we?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: We do... What do you think of Missy?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: She’s very pleasant. But she perplexes me. Words in our language are either masculine or feminine. There’s no word for Missy.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh, I know one...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You seem content, for once. Isn't there something missing?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? INT. COUNTRY HOUSE - STAIRS/COLETTE’S BEDROOM 142 Colette and Missy run up the stairs laughing, wild with passion. They round the door and start to kiss hotly. Missy puts her hand down Colette’s skirts and starts to pleasure her. It’s a new level of erotic engagement for Colette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next door, a different kind of scene. Willy is waiting expectantly on a chaise longue. A quiet knock on the door Meg's voice comes from the outside...

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Ready. .?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m ready.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 89. She shuffles out in a full Claudine smock and stands simpering at the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: My name is Claudine. I live in Montigny. I was born there in...(she calculates) Should I change the year?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No. Keep it the same.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I was born in 1881...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: I will probably not die there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunshine and bird song. By the weatherworn gym equipment, Missy holds Colette’s feet as she does sit ups on the horse.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: 48...49...50. Well done... Colette finishes breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Missy, you were married once, weren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Yes, it was awful... We don’t talk anymore, except through the auspices of lawyers. He’s embarrassed by me - if he was married to me, what does that say about him?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It must have been very hard for you, I mean, to put on the trousers..?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: No, it was entirely natural. I was a rather awkward child - if you can imagine me in pigtails and a dress. I never felt like I belonged. Then one day I tried on my brother’s school uniform. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MISSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I knew I was home for the first time... Of course, it’s far easier for me than for women of no means... but I wanted to show that it can be done. I do imagine a time when all women may wear trousers if that is their wish. Colette smiles, reflecting. MISSY (CONT’D) And you?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Well, I dress as a man; Willy dresses you as a schoolgirl.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (ironically) Thank you. (takes a breath) I do know what I’m doing, you know. I’m in on the joke.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I don’t doubt it. But are you happy?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Is anybody happy? Willy’s demanding - yes, but he gives me a lot of freedom.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: It’s a long leash he keeps you on but a leash nevertheless... perhaps you enjoy that.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Do you think that’s terribly wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: No. That’s entirely your business. But... never mind.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 91.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Well, I wonder if a time will come when you have to decide - are you Claudine or are you Colette? Colette absorbs this and looks away. 145 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S BUILDING - STAIRCASE - DAY 1 Colette ascends the stairs to her own apartment - wearing suit and trousers. 146 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - DAY 146 She goes through the apartment towards Willy’s study. Pau Héon is working at his desk by the door.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Hello Héon.

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: Hello Colette.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Is he there?

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What kind of mood is he in?

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: The usual. But worse. 147 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - WILLY’S STUDY - Willy is pawing over an account ledger as she enters.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Morning Willy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My word. What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: They're Missy's.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My Dear, I’m surprised you didn’t get arrested. Or beaten up. Colette shrugs this off.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 92.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy...I’ve was thinking. You know ‘Claudine Takes Off’ - why don’t we publish it under both our names?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Out of the question. Ollendorff will never agree.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Ollendorff or you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My dear, do you want to the kill the goose that’s laying the golden Claudines? Colette is exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: But there’s little risk. Claudine’s established... And many people, they know already... or suspect ...Surely.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No one knows. Unless you've been crowing about it to your lady man friend.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t insult Missy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I think she is stripping you of your sense of humour...and your common sense.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: That’s not fair Willy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We can’t risk it. Especially not with our present finances. We’re dead broke.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: We're always broke! Yet you gamble and fill this place with all your antiques.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: They were bought from bankrupts at a debtor’s auction!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: The car. The racehorse that went lame?  148 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 93.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: ..-And you? Your clothes, your hats, the exorbitant mortgage on the country house.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (adamant ) I want my name on the book.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No no no. Willy is a brand name. And the fact is, women writers don’t sell. Colette lets out a gasp of frustration.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Bastard! Selfish, smug, fat, lazy bastard!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’ll give you fat... All the other descriptions are libel.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I need credit for my work! My name on it!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Utter nonsense! If you were so concerned about that you never should have agreed to it all.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Godammit Willy..!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Without the progenitor, there would be no Claudine! Colette takes his pile of papers and throws them on the floor and marches out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is thick, humid, charged with electricity. Colette walks through the gloomy streets, lost in her own thoughts. She feels small, disinherited, angry. She walks towards the Seine and looks out over the water. Down by the quayside a YOUNG CLAUDINE is with her SWEETHEART, flirting and kissing. Colette looks despondently at something she created but cannot own. FADE TO BLACK.  149 150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ivories of a piano are being hammered. A BOHEMIAN PIANIST is playing a rhythmic Oriental piece. Light bounces around the studio, with its polished floors and huge mirrors. Four YOUNG DANCERS in leotards crawl on all fours. WAGUE, the renowned mime, is teaching a class. The door opens. Colette enters. Watches the class in action. Wague notices her presence, nods curtly, and continues. Colette starts to take off her outer clothes, she wears a leotard underneath. HALF AN HOUR LATER The dancers gather their things. Colet enters now changed into a leotard with her clothes ina bag.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: Let’s get to work. A short montage as Wague demonstrates various motions tha Colette diligently copies. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DAY 15 Willy is reading a newspaper. Colette is in front of a mi with a sheet of chiffon draped around her, practicing movement. Matilde is on her knees cleaning the hearth.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Are you going to write today?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. I’m rehearsing with Wague later.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Don’t you think you ought to? What are your priorities? (he looks at her, frustrated) I should start locking you up again.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I would scream the house down. She carries on with the exercises, self-absorbed.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 95.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s a charming hobby, Tetette but... You are not Sarah Bernhardt. And if you can’t pull it off as high art you’ll be doing the bloody music halls, for god’s sake. And that would be scandalous.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: And when have you ever considered scandal a bad thing?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: True...What does Missy say?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: He’s all for it. He comes along to Wague’s studio with me all the time.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: How depressing. Does she have no life of her own whatsoever?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Missy does the movements with me. He’s rather good. Willy nods - he’s having one of his famous ‘big ideas.’ COLETTE (CONT’D) Wague thinks I could be a ready for the stage in a few weeks. What do you think, Matilde?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDE
dialogues.text: I have to agree with M. Willy, Ma’am. It’s not very lady-like.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I thought you were on my side!

dialogues.speaker: MATILDE
dialogues.text: Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: So you and the Marquise run around the studio as potty mimetic lovers do you? (Colette nods) And Missy shares your ambition to go on the stage?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Oh no, he’s far too shy.  151 152 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy is pitching a THEATRE MANAGER after a heavy lunch.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’ll be called “The Dream of Egypt.” Paris will never have seen anything like it. A scandalous sensation - starring Madame Colette Willy and... (drumroll on the table) The Marquise de Belbeuf!!! In the common or garden music hall! Can you imagine? It’ll be a full house. Every night.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: We do perfectly well with the can-can.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’ve seen it half empty on a week night.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You can vouch for the Marquise?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s in the bag. We can even put the Belbeuf family crest on the poster. The press will go wild. You mark my words.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Do you have backers?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I only need one. Myself.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You're that confident? That’s a lot of capital. Willy bluffs somewhat - in his eyes, a slight worry.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A theatrical poster on a column outside the Moulin Rouge announces the premiere of "Dream of Egypt," starring Mme. Colette Willy and the mystery performer "YSSIM." Excited crowds gather outside the famous red windmill, anticipating a big night.  153 154 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 97. INT. MOULIN ROUGE — THE MAIN ROOM 153 The place is filling up - Rachilde, Veber, Schwob, Madame de Caillavet with Gaston and Jeanne and many SALONITES. O stage, stands a large, solitary sarcophagus. Willy, accompanied by Meg, makes his way to a table near the stage, greeting various folk.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: My God, there’s Maurice Ravel - and there’s Madame de Caillavet...all of our friends are here.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, a lot of the Marquis’ friends are here too. He indicates a block-booking of starchy-looking aristocra near the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house lights come down, precipitating a wave of wolf whistles and cat calls. Up on a balcony, a man dressed as ANUBIS strikes a gong. A SMALL ORCHESTRA strikes up a moo Arabian theme.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Here we go. The curtain goes up on a set resembling the interior of a Egyptian tomb — hieroglyphics, statues etc. Missy enters the stage woodenly, dressed as an archeologist, reading from an old book. The crowd ROARS. shower of coins, orange peel and garlic cloves rains on t stage. Undaunted, Missy finds a cartouche on the sarcophagus and carefully brushes the dust off it.

dialogues.speaker: HECKLER
dialogues.text: Get a move on, you dyke! Then, with great effort, Missy opens the lid of the sarcophagus. The lights change. The orchestra ramps up. And something starts to appear. In the crowd various people react: Mme. de Caillavet, sneering TOP-HATTED GENTLEMEN, Veber, Schwob, Gaston de Caillavet. Willy watches intently, picking up on every mu of the crowd.  155 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 98. Emerging from the sarcophagus is Colette, cross-legged in bejeweled outfit inspired by Salome. The audience gasps. Rhythmic music kicks in and Colette starts to do a series of evocative movements. Missy watches her in stagy wonder Some audience members are delighted, others appalled.

dialogues.speaker: A POSH HECKLER
dialogues.text: Degenerate! Get back to Lesbos! Now the dance is really heating up. Colette comes down fr the pedestal and starts to dance. Missy joins in, framing Colette’s gyrations with her own eccentric movements. As the crowd starts to boil over, Willy’s eyes are shinin At the climax of the dance, Colette falls into the Marquise’s arms. Their lips move closer and closer — a hu GASP comes up from the house. Then... THEY KISS. The house EXPLODES. People are on their feet, yelling and booing. A barrage of food and glasses are thrown onto the stage, smashing around the embracing couple - even a footstool, which Colette narrowly dodges. The curtain falls.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (to Meg) It may be time to go... But the rioting audience turn on them.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER HECKLER
dialogues.text: Cuckold! Cuckold!! A crowd of RUFFIANS advance on Willy and Meg. Willy brand his cane, keeping them off as he and Meg make their way t door. Somebody grabs Meg’s hair and she punches him in th face. The whole auditorium is in a state of revolt. INT. MOULIN ROUGE — BACK STAGE 155 Anubis, now without his headdress, is talking to a REPORTER, whose attention is suddenly distracted as Colet and Missy exit their dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Madame Colette, what are your impressions of tonight?  156 157 158 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 99.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (firing on all cylinders) My ‘impressions?’ I’m disgusted. These people who threw things are cowards - if I didn’t get a footstool in the face, it’s only because I dodged it.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Let it go, Colette. (to reporter) There were some gentleman there who came for a fight. We just have to ignore them and go on.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: So you intend to continue?

dialogues.speaker: MISSY COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. Yes! COLETTE (cont'd) (CONT'D) They don’t scare me at all. Look am I trembling..? (holds out her hand) I will continue to pursue this because I am an artist and a free woman and if Paris won’t have me -- so be it! I’ll go elsewhere to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a country graveyard, a coffin is going into the ground COUNTRY PRIEST reads the rites. The family are assembled the funeral of JULES COLETTE. Sido is clearly beside hers with grief. Colette is there - deep in grief, with Willy sneaks a look at his watch. This doesn’t go unnoticed by Sido.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 157
dialogues.text: INT. COLETTE FAMILY HOUSE - COLETTE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 158 Colette unlaces a boot and drops it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: How are you bearing up my love?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ..-I keep thinking I’1l see him in every room. But he’s gone.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 100.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: He was an old soldier. A good solid man.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: He was..."“was”... Colette sighs, puzzled by death - exhausted. WILLY (cont'd) I saw our creditors yesterday. Horrific. We lost everything at the Moulin Rouge.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy - not today.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Tetette, we need to sell the country house. Colette is brought up short.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. No, Willy. You can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Morally, yes, I need your permission. But legally, well, the house is in my name...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Or we file for bankruptcy. What do you think? She throws her other boot to the corner of the room. Sits there, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, Willy walks around the garden, smokin Colette brings a dirty plate up to Sido at the kitchen sink.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: You need to divorce him, Gabri, and quick.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 101.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Sido, don’t...please.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: You ask for a full audit of his accounts, and...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: You must face reality. The money. His infidelities. And his lies! I never believe a word he says. Not like Missy - so kind and generous and honest.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: We should be thinking about papa.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: He’s dead. You’re alive. Willy’s a mess. A drinker. A gambler. He’s a broken man, Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that. She glances out to see Willy in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: He’ll hold you back.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: But...I still...

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Gabri, You have to use your gifts. Forget this “pantomime”! Please! Write something new - under your own name.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m going on tour, Sido, with Wague - for the next six months. The contracts are being drawn up. We're doing a new piece...

dialogues.speaker: SIDO
dialogues.text: Oh no, Gabrielle! Get out of it. You have to.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m going to do it. Writing’s a nightmare. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All the hours I spent with him breathing down my neck - the turn of the key in the lock, the ache in my fingers. I’m done with it. Willy appears -- immediately sensing an atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What did I miss..? Both women carry on with their kitchen duties without replying. WILLY (CONT’D) Women...knives...all very Greek. Colette averts her eyes, unable to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aerial shot over fields and hedges finds a steam train speeding along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train has pulled in. Amongst the disembarking passenger a TROUPE OF MUSIC HALL PERFORMERS. We follow them down th platform: There are SHOWGIRLS, ACROBATS, DOG TRAINERS, A MAGICIAN. Colette and Wague are with them, dragging a tru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining. The troupe walk to the stage door. Outside theater a poster announcing the various acts including Mm Colette Willy and Wague in “FLESH.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette stares at herself in the dressing table mirror wi a kind of melancholy blankness. She is thirty-three years old now and she looks tired. There’s a knock at the door. It’s Wague.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: Colette -  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 103.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Wague, I don’t know if I’m up to it today. I haven’t slept a wink for the last two nights. I have flea bites all over. I’m exhausted!

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: We’re all bloody exhausted! She snorts. WAGUE (CONT’D) Have you got any kohl I could borrow?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. Catch. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: You’1l survive. He exits. Colette turns back to the mirror and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the scene set for a peasant’s cottage, Colette is flirting with a SECRET LOVER. The AUDIENCE is not paying much attention - they are drinking, talking, eating. Wague, playing Colette’s husband, discovers them and has fit of jealous rage; he shoves Colette around, smashing dishes and goes to attack the lover. Colette pleads and tries to explain (silently, of course) but Wague’s rage just builds. He goes to attack the lover but Colette gets in between them. Wague grabs her collar and TEARS IT ASUNDER REVEALING HER BREAST. Shocked he prostrates himself on the stage as tho struck by lightning. The audience is awestruck. Colette stands frozen in her p as the piano restarts. We see something in her expression the exhilaration that comes with discovering a new source personal power.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 104. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - WILLY’S STUDY - DAY1 Willy is looking helplessly through a stack of bills. He looks like he’s recovering from a rough night. Moments later, he is at his desk in front of a typewriter He cracks his knuckles and prepares to work. In front of him is the GREAT BLANK PAGE. He types “WHAT CLAUDINE DID NEXT.” Then, “A NOVEL BY WILL But nothing will come. The page remains blank. He stares it with growing frustration. He types a letter, the word “I.” Then dots. ..... I... I. then just scrambles on the typewriter anything. HJIDGJYGEBNFJH jhgiuyi8t/[108450io0df jnaf;knakgjhuyatuhr He stops. Then... KSJhdiuyrug jhabvdf jhqyt5pquojbf ’ auyt[ 085yioqhohhtuhw He types faster and faster and faster and starts to bang the keys - first with fingers then with his fists so that he is likely to hurt himself. Then he stops, breathes and almost at the point of tears, and looks desperately at a picture of Colette on his desk. INT. OLLENDORFF PUBLISHING — DAY 168 Willy walks slowly up the grand staircase. INT. OLLENDORFF’S OFFICE - DAY 169 The men are seated on either side of Ollendorff'’s wide desk, igniting cigars.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Tell me something...the sole rights to the Claudines, Ollendorff... What would you give me for them?

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Are you serious? All of them?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Make me an offer.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: How much are you thinking?  170 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 105.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Let’s say 25,000. In a few years - they’1l recoup ten times that.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Possibly...but I don’t have that much. Publishing is a volatile business, Willy...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) How much then?

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: ..-For the sole rights in perpetuity?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Ollendorff eyes him, calculating. He takes a small slip o paper and scribbles a number on it and passes it over the desk. Willy looks at it, dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warm crowded table in a lively low-roofed cellar filled with life and music. Colette and BAPTISTE, a Vietnamese conjurer, are having an arm wrestle across a table. Wague with a YOUNG FLIRT, a RUSSIAN ACROBAT and some SHOWGIRLS cheer Colette on. There is the feeling of merriment, of circus. Colette almost loses then makes a final mighty pu to bring her opponent’s hand down. Cheers from the assembled.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Did you let me win?

dialogues.speaker: BAPTISTE
dialogues.text: Of course!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Bastard! That’s worst than losing!

dialogues.speaker: ACROBAT
dialogues.text: (to Baptiste) How about it..? The Acrobat offers his arm for a wrestle to the Baptiste.

dialogues.speaker: BAPTISTE
dialogues.text: No no. I have a great affection for my arm.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 106. Laughter. Across the room, Missy enters at the main door. Wearing a SKIRT.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Missy! Missy! Missy expertly detaches the skirt revealing trousers underneath. Everybody cheers.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Hello, my love.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry the train was waiting for two hours at the Gard du Nord.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Come here...next to me. Missy snuggles on to the bench by Colette.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: How was it tonight?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It was like every night. Sheer terror and then bliss.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: The gang is in a good mood.

dialogues.speaker: BAPTISTE
dialogues.text: Hey Missy, I’m going to the bar do you want anything?-

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Order champagne. Three bottles. Make it five. Everyone cheers. A drunken showgirl, FLOSSY, plants a kis on Colette’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: FLOSSY
dialogues.text: Santé, you beautiful gal.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Santé, Flossy. You’re the best.

dialogues.speaker: FLOSSY
dialogues.text: You can give it and you can take it... We loves ya, don’t we, Moll?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 107. Her friend, MOLLY, agrees. Colette’s eyes glow at this compliment - far greater and more meaningful than any she received in the salon. Baptiste pops the champagne cork to more cheers. It seems like the party will go on all night. 171 INT. COLETTE’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 171 A small pokey hotel room. Colette and Missy undress for b by candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: We had a cancellation in Limoges - I have four days off next week.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Are you coming back to Paris?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No. I have to go up to Besancon - to pack up the house.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Will he be there?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Missy, it’s been a long day. Can’t we just...

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m sorry. They get into bed and hold each other close. MISSY (CONT’D) You don’t need to worry about Willy. You don’t need to earn your own money or stay in these kind of places. I could arrange everything.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Too much of my life has been “arranged.”

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I just want you to be able to write if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. I’m happy. And I like my threadbare lodgings...I like making my own money. Even if it’s only 50 francs a show.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 108. Missy nods, hiding her hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: I love you. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: ...Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: It’s not the traditional reply but I‘1l take it for now. They stare into each other’s eyes. There’s a pounding on door.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Get up. Now! We’re coming in. Colette stands using a blanket to cover herself as the MANAGER opens the door with his WIFE in tow.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Out! Both of you! Get out of here! MANAGER'‘S WIFE You see? I told you!

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: You degenerates! MANAGER’‘S WIFE We don’t have filth under our roof.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: You’ve got five minutes to get out or I’m calling the police.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Please fuck off. (alternate take) Oh bugger off. He slams the door. Colette looks distraught.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What are we going to do now? I have to be up at six to catch the train to Nice.  172 173 174 175 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 109.

dialogues.speaker: MISSY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, my dear. We’1ll find somewhere else... Colette looks into Missy’s eyes and finds strength there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC COMES UP. Hastily, dressed, Colette and Missy desce the stairs with their bags, past the manager with their heads held high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the exiled lovers walk off into the darkness, Missy takes Colette’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain clouds gather over the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house has taken on a depressing air - pictures have been taken down, furniture has been moved out. Colette is packaging up her collection of paperweights. Across the room, Willy is packing up some bric-a-brac. They work in silence, at opposite ends of a wide frame.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking about this new craze for moving pictures. Do you think we could adapt Claudine for a cineplay..?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: (half to herself) Do you never stop?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We could write a completely fresh story. Claudine by the Sea.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No... Adapt the old ones...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Perhaps... There’s a flash of guilt in Willy’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Catch!  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 110. She throws the original Paris snow globe across to him. H the water has leaked out and it looks pretty deteriorated

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh yes! How sad. Tears come to his eyes but she doesn’t see. WILLY (CONT’D) I’ve missed you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No, you haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of course I have... your ambiguous smiles, the insane speed of your thoughts, your absurd joys, your brief but violent anger... Colette is affected by this but won’t let it show. She finishes up a crate and puts the lid on.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: How’s the book going with Meg..?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Terrible! All spice and no literature. (Colette snorts a laugh) She’s not you and she never will be. Colette sighs. The tug of old forces on her heart.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What are we doing, Willy? They look across to each other but the distance between them seems now unbreachable.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: ...Are we finished?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Willy sighs, wants to cry. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You can’t.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Why can’t I?  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 111.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Because I love you and you at your most brilliant with me.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, you know you are. But you still need your headmaster... 176 INT. COLETTE’S BEDROOM - COUNTRY HOUSE - NIGHT 176 Colette lies awake, troubled. There’s a light knock.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Come in. Willy enters, dressed in his nightshirt.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: May I get in with you, Gabri?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: - Yes. Get in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t sleep. It was too quiet. (a quiet moment) Listen. The silence. It’s terrifying isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No...I love it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of course, you do - you country girl. He kisses her on the cheek. WILLY (CONT’D) I have something weighing on me...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: What. .?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I...I don’t sleep with Meg any more. I mean we sleep. But I can’t... Willy cannot say it.  177 178 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 112.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It does. It matters very much. She holds him close, as if he were a child.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Good-night, my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience are applauding. Up on stage Colette and her music hall troupe bow together holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troupe descend a spiral staircase leading down from t stage. Colette is next to Wague, exhausted after her performance. Flossy turns round out.

dialogues.speaker: FLOSSY
dialogues.text: Went well tonight! Colette waves her hand indicating so-so. She turns to go some steps when a voice calls out for her.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Madame Willy.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Monsieur Ollendorff! They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: I'm here in Lille on some family business, and I was delighted when I found out you were here with the play.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: It’s kind of you to come and see it.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: It was quite a spectacle. Colette gives him a tight-lipped smile. Two SHOWGIRLS com down the stairs and bustle past them up. OLLENDORFF (cont'd) (CONT'D) I was thinking, if you were free, I would like to take you and the Marquise to dinner.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 113.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’m always up for a free feed. And especially in such august company.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: It’s the very least I can do for you, Colette. After all the money you’ve made for me. And will continue to make. (he gives a tight-lipped smile) I wish I had been able to give Willy a better settlement. But one can only pay what one can afford.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I quite understand.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: For the Claudines. For the rights to the Claudines. A STAGEHAND passes between them carrying a bunch of flowe up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mean to say he didn’t tell you? Colette looks at him stunned.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy sold you the Claudines?

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Yes. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: He sold you Claudines...

dialogues.speaker: OLLENDORFF
dialogues.text: Absolutely. I’m sorry. I thought. .? Colette struggles to keep herself under control.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: How much did he get for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colette speeds along, gazing out of the window. 180 EXT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - STAIRCASE - DAY Colette flies up the stairs in a rage.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 114. 181 INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - WILLY’S STUDY — Paul Héon sit typing while Willy stands, giving dictation Colette is at the door, livid.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: ..-I am most insulted by the implication of your letter. We have transacted business now for over five years without any... Colette storms in.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Willy, I need to see you alone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Tetette! What a wonderful surprise! Sensing the impending storm, Héon rises, makes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: I’1l see you later, Willy, Colette. He leaves the two of them alone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: So? She just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: 5000 francs, Willy. 5000 francs...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ah... You've heard... Yes... Well...I was in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Traitor. Liar. Thief.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Don’t be so melodramatic. I was trying to keep the house for you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I gave you the house!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We still owed the bank so much on it.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 115.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You could have sold Veber’s novels. Some of your other trash. You only did it to stick the knife in me. Didn’t you?! DIDN’T you?!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t have got anything for Veber’s or Schwob’s or anyone else’s. Please calm down...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Why? Why should I calm down? You hurt and you hurt and you think that by saying “I’m aman, that’s what men do,” you clear it all away... He reaches for her hand. She explodes, recoils as if at a electric shock. COLETTE (CONT’D) DON’T YOU TOUCH ME! What you did was not just hateful - it was stupid. Now we'll have no say over our books and we'll never see another sou from them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We can write some more...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: No! Never again! NEVER!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My dear, you’re over-reacting. It was purely a business decision.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: That’s what our whole marriage has been! Wasn’t I the best investment you ever made? No dowry but my God, she can write for her keep?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
