dialogues.text: If you were an investment then you were a highly speculative one. I gave up my inheritance for you.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: I paid you back a thousand times.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Colette stop, damn it!! Stop talking about money. You were my ideal, my obsession, my love.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 116. Colette catches her breath and slowly turns to him. Her eyes are burning. When she speaks, it is with unexpected calm.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: You've killed our child. Willy stares at her, stunned. COLETTE (CONT’D) Those books — they were all we had. Now they’re gone and we’ve no chance of repair.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My dear, Claudine was only a...

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t! Don’t tell me what Claudine was. I am the real Claudine!!! (he tries to interrupt) Everything I thought and felt went into those books. They were me. My childhood, my memories, my opinions. Everything. And then the hours and hours I spent, alone, slaving away for you. Churning out scenes just to try and please you. I am so ashamed of myself for that. But I knew and you knew - that I was bound to do it. (she shakes her head) You found me when I knew nothing, Willy. You molded me to your own designs...to your desires. And you thought I could never break free... But you’re wrong. Claudine is dead now. She’s gone. You betrayed her. And I...I’ve outgrown her. Willy sinks into a chair. He looks exhausted, deflated. H has finally broken. She walks

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Please, my dear, I was stupid... I panicked... forgive me. Please.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Willy. to the door. Willy’s tone turns.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No...Tetette...Gabrielle....My love...Stop! I forbid you..!  182 183 184 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 117. She leaves, closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening is coming on. The street of Paris are busy with cars. The electric street lamps turn off automatically. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT —- MORNING 183 Willy is looking through the exercise books. Page after p of Colette school notebooks, - the original text of the Claudine novels with the occasional margin note from Will He is thinking out loud to Heon...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You see - that’s mine, that’s mine - it was a collaboration... she really has a nerve... These prove it. Heon says nothing. Willy reads his silence. WILLY (CONT’D) You know... Could you do me a favor, Héon? Could you destroy these for me?

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Definitely. Burn them. Incinerate.

dialogues.speaker: HEON
dialogues.text: Yes, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (sighs) I’m going out. He heads out the door. Leaving Héon with the books. INT. CAFE NOIR — MORNING 184 Willy and Schwob sitting at a dark table nursing an absinthe. A chess set is in front of them but they are barely interested in the game.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: ..-How many decent salons are left now? Two, maybe three.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: It’s the end of a dream.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Paris is losing its gold.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, I must confess, I don’t think that this century agrees with me quite as much as the last one.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: I haven’t heard from Colette. I’ve written to her twice but no word.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Writing is anathema to her, it always has been.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: You two really are done this time?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: She’‘ll pass me on the street and not even look at me. “Claudine Divorced.” So much the worse for her. And for me... 118. A solemn silence. Across the bar a YOUNG WOMAN (who we remember as LILY - GEORGIE’S ASSISTANT) and her GIRLFRIEN are having coffee at the bar. She says something to her then ventures across the room.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: M. Willy?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I am the late Monsieur Willy.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I'm Lily - Lily Milson. I met you once. Years ago. I used to work for Madame Raoul Duval.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh yes! I saw you and your friend come in and I thought - what wonderful young creatures! Thank heaven for... you, my dear This embarrasses Lily.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say hello.  185 186 187 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 119.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Well, how about you two come and share a drink with a couple of old roués? He gives her a come on look through bleary eyes. Schwob l embarrassed. WILLY (CONT’D) (CONT'D) It’s never too early... He pats the seat beside him. Lily looks disillusioned, sa

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (nervously) I’m sorry, I have to go... Very nice seeing you. And she’s gone. Willy stares sadly into his drink.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWOB
dialogues.text: Loosing your touch...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Lost! The Claudines are done with their headmaster. He downs the last dregs and sighs. INT. COLETTE AND WILLY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 185 Héon stokes up the fire in Willy’s study. He takes the fi book and is about to throw in on. Then he stops, opens th book and looks at the words for a moment. Taking a decision, he puts all the books in a leather satchel, and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING 186
dialogues.text: The train whizzes through the countryside as evening fall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is asleep except Colette, who leans against the side of the compartment, staring into the blackness. Then Missy stirs. She catches Colette’s eye. Colette returns her gaze with a tired smile, and mouths - I Love You.  188 189 190 191 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three find their way to the theater that displays a giant poster for “FLESH.” INT. DRESSING ROOM — EVENING 189 At the venue, Colette is getting dressed. She pulls on a stocking but her big toe pokes through it. It’s torn.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Shit! She goes over to a large trunk in the corner, opens it up and rifles around in the tattered sequin gowns. At the bottom of the trunk, she finds something that stops her i her tracks. It is one of her school notebooks - the last one of the original Claudine At School manuscript. She fl through it and about a third of the way in finds the page that says THE END. Wague sticks his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: WAGUE
dialogues.text: Thirty minutes to curtain.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Wague. She blows him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER 190
dialogues.text: The nib of a pen is dipped in ink. On the opposite page f the end of Claudine, Colette writes “NOTES ON THE MUSIC H She starts to write again - we hear a new authority in he voice.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After two years of music-hall and theatre, I’m still the same — face to face with that painted mentor who gazes at me from the other side of the looking-glass, with deep-set eyes under lids smeared with purplish greasepaint. INT. CORRIDOR — NIGHT 191 Colette walks down the corridor backstage, past SHOWGIRLS changing and ACROBATS warming up - her new world, her new community. She sees Wague who signals to her good luck.  192 COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 121.

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know she is going to speak to me. She is going to say: "Is that you there, all alone under that ceiling booming and vibrating under the feet of the dancers? Why are you there, all alone? And why not somewhere else?” Yes, this is the dangerous, lucid hour. Approaching the stage, we hear the audience chanting "Col over and over in rhythm. The sound gets louder, the audie feet beating a tattoo on the floor; COLETTE, COLETTE, COL INT. THEATRE — BACKSTAGE 192

dialogues.speaker: COLETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now, whenever I despair, I no longer expect my end, but some bit of luck, some commonplace little miracle which, like a glittering link, will mend again the necklace of my days. Colette takes a deep breath. The curtain goes up, to thun applause. She walks into the brilliant glow of the footli and disappears into white, like a bird disappearing into sun. TITLES comes up, accompanied by ARCHIVAL PHOTOS and MUSIC

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: In 1911, Colette’s “The Vagabond,” based on her music hall experience, was published under her own name to great critical acclaim. TITLE (CONT’D) Missy and Colette continued their relationship for many years. Missy often accompanied Colette on her music hall tours, though never again opted to appear on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Willy continued to publish ghost- written books with Meg, but failed to replicate the success of the Claudines. He died in 1931 in relative obscurity.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul Héon did not destroy the original Claudine manuscripts but returned them to Colette. They became crucial evidence in a 1948 legal battle to establish the true authorship of the novels... that Colette won.  COLETTE - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 122.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Colette went on to publish over fifty acclaimed novels and short stories. She became the most celebrated female author in the history of French literature. In her old age, Colette remarked, “What a wonderful life I’ve had. I only wish I’d realized it sooner.”
